reviewText:
How this has mostly positive reviews is surprising to me, maybe they are because it only costs $10 I suppose? For only $10 I guess I can see it's appeal maybe for the seasonal interest?

However the plot becomes obvious within about the first 15 minutes, and no there isn't any twist by that far you have probably figured out almost the entire plot.
The gameplay is about an hour long, maybe 10-20 minutes longer if you intentionally go as slow as possible to collect and read every note page.

Half of it is on rails, as in you literally just sit and watch, the other half is just following a path and reading papers you find, that is it, there is no gameplay beyond that.

However what really makes me say this game isn't worth it wasn't all that. I actually think for only $10 it still has enough intrigue, and provided enough of a very short thrill that maybe it could have been a 6/10 game rather than a 4/10 or less type game.  They should have more developed and used these creepy beings, and tried to create something you can get excited about- because that never happened for me. When you finally feel the game might be getting to it's highest peak (which would be the minimum requirements of any other decent title), it just ends. It cuts short without delivering what you probably bought the game hoping for.

All in all this is about as a scary as say, something goosebumps related, but it was intended for adults with an adult theme; which might have been fine had it been excuted properly.

However it is halloween, so if you want to give it a go and literally don't care about spending $10 for one hour of medicore entertainment, then go for it, it is not the worst game you could play, and it does have a few legitimately creepy moments. I only just barely don't recommend it simply because it could have just been a tiny bit longer to give them the time and room to actually deliver on their suspense, or to flush out the rides, or something more in depth to add some actual gameplay element of some kind.

(Ps: Since I know people looking at reviews love to look at playtime, I stopped to actually read every single letter I could find in detail, and doubled back in some areas, and finished in about an hour and 10 minutes, the other 10 wasn't game time.
Also if your game crashes a few times on start up, it seems to just go away for the rest of the play session when you get it up and running, at least I hope- it stopped after a few start up crashes for me anyways)

reviewText:
The Park is an immersive game with an interesting setting and good story telling.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BzpAGnmKWRk
You play as a mother who goes into an amusement park after her kid runs off. The place is filled dark corners, creepy faces and eerie notes. The game is similar to Dear Esther and Gone Home in the sense that there is no action or combat. It's simply a story-telling game.

The notes you find shed some light on some events that might have happened in the park. As you play through the game, you uncover more of the interesting story. Luckily, the voice acting is good, because there's quiet a lot of it. Your character will talk to herself when she sees certain objects, or describe a memory when you walk somewhere. It's interesting to listen to it all because it's nicely written.

Apart from having basic interaction with stuff like notes, you can also right click to call out to your son, which will also give a visual representation of where you can go next incase you are feeling a bit lost.

The environment itself is pretty spooky. Plastic faces of mascots, and a few shadowy figures. There are jumpscares, but they're didn't manage to annoy me like most games do. The game isn't filled with them, and they only really happen because you're on edge from other stuff.

Keep in mind, the game can be beaten in around 2 hours if you fully explore and read everything, so it is a short experience, however I found it an enjoyable one. Overall, a well sculpted game with good story telling!

reviewText:
Published by: Funcom
Developed by: Funcom
Genre: Adventure/Psychological Horror/Walking Simulator
Release Date: October 27, 2015

Delve deep into the mind of a troubled woman searching for her son in this creepy yet enticing horror experience.

WarningThis game is heavily centered around the fragility of the main characterâ€™s disturbed mind. As such, this game tackles some pretty heavy/unpleasant themes, and may cause emotional distress for some.

IntroductionAfter her son Callum runs into â€˜Atlantic Island Parkâ€™ after hours, Lorraine must venture her way through the chilling macabre amusement park to find him.
The heavily narrated â€˜gameâ€™ is more aptly considered a story or an experience; there is no combat or action involved, and very few interactions available.
The Park has mastered psychological horror perfectly, not relying on cheap jump scares or excessive gore, yet still managing to scare the player witless. The dark and disturbing scenery adds to the unnerving atmosphere of the game, and makes it easy to become fully engrossed in the story and the character you are following.

StoryLorraine first appears as the average mother, speaking of her worries and struggles as a parent. Venturing further into the park, and further into Lorraineâ€™s thoughts, you realise that she is far from average. As you follow Lorraineâ€™s journey, you begin to question the validity on what she is experiencing. Her paranoia and obvious mental instability are further emphasised as the game progresses, most evident towards the end of the game, with clues about her past shown in cutscenes throughout.
There is a clever parallel to a childrenâ€™s fairy tale evident in the game. Similarities are shown through Lorraineâ€™s stories (if you really pay attention), and hints are present throughout.

GameplayAs this is more of a walking simulator, there really isnâ€™t much to the game in terms of difficulty/challenge/gameplay. Essentially all you are able to do is walk/run, and interact with a few objects (usually notes or similar). You are also able to ride the few attractions in the game.
Because the game is more of a short narrative, there is no real replay value to it, and it takes roughly 1-2 hours to complete the entire game.

Voice ActingThe Voice acting in this game is tremendous. The most chilling and unsettling part about this game isnâ€™t the jump scares, the gruesome scenes you read about in the notes or the creepy park mascot, Chad, seemingly stalking you throughout the game. Itâ€™s the perfectly illustrated story, the emotion behind every word told by Lorraine, portrayed by Fryda Wolff. You can feel the struggles Lorraine is experiencing, the dread in her voice as she recalls past events. What makes this game go from good to great, is Frydaâ€™s portrayal of Lorraine.

GraphicsThe graphics are fairly standard. Thereâ€™s nothing over the top spectacular in this department, but it is still a pleasant viewing experience.

Overall VerdictThe Park is an immersive psychological horror experience, definitely worth getting if you like the genre. The storyline is compelling, and itâ€™s definitely a game that will stick with you.

Overall Score: 8/10

reviewText:
Game:  The Park
Publisher:  Funcom
Developer:  Funcom
Steam Release Date:  October 27, 2015
Genre:  Walking Simulator, Psychological Horror

Oh Funcom, how this game adds to my love-hate relationship with you...

About the Game and the Universe it's set in
The Park is set within the dark, fictional world of the MMORPG The Secret World, and as such, manages to retain alot of the feel and atmosphere of the game in this single player installment. Many people who have played TSW will recognize that this is the exact same amusement park they get to play around in after leaving Kingsmouth, albiet the TSW version is rundown and abandoned. If you didn't notice it was the same amusement park, perhaps it's time to delve into the lovecraftian themed mmo again.

The Park is a walking simulator game with psychological horror elements, however, the game also is very story driven and focuses on exploration of the environment as well.

You are Lorraine, a young single mother, who has taken her brat... I mean child... to the Atlantic Park, and just as you are getting ready to leave, find out that your childs favorite teddybear is lost. Like any good parent, you go to the information to see if it is in the lost and found bin (instead of being like any NORMAL parent who buys another one for the brat), and as you're talking with the information staff you find that your son has run into the the amusement park.

Conveniently, the park is starting to close for the day, and the friendly staff member who knows you on a first name basis lets you back into the park to catch your son. As you enter the park, the lights magically change from afternoon to the witching hour and your brat has run so far ahead that it is impossible to catch up with him.. that and the fact you spend your time leisurely riding each ride you come across instead of actually trying to find him.

The deeper you get into The Park, and the more you explore, the higher the fear is, and the more you realize that there is something dark, unwelcoming, and unloving about the park.

The good
This game has alot of good going for it, almost enough to make you overlook the fact that it is a Funcom game.... almost..

+ Graphics are absolutely goregous and run smoothly, character model faces however, use the same engine as TSW, which for me was lackluster.
+ Sound effects are not loud and overpowering
+ Superb voice acting for Lorraine. You can hear the fear in her voice at times, as well as the anger later on in the game.
+ Easy achievements for those who care about those things.
+ Very atmospheric and immersive given the genre and length of game.
+ Player Character is very relatable, isnt a super hero.

The Ugly - Right away I crashed. A great reminder that this game was indeed, a Funcom game.
- Length of game was rather short, and the first half of the game felt a bit forced to me... another great reminder that this is a Funcom game.
- Lack of ability to jump or traverse uneven terrain. This really irks me, because for a game that wants you to explore, you're limited to JUST the park paths.
- Game not overly scary. For a psychological horror game I was expecting more... well... psychological horror.. and in fact I only had three moments where I was genuinely creeped out before the last twenty minutes of the game.
-I did not actually care for the ending. I wont go into details why, but for me, it was just underwhelming.
- About 80% of the notes, letters, and other clues were mostly unreadable to the normal eye. I had to get really close to the screen to make out the clues. (Thanks SuperDean for reminding me of this!)

The Conclusion
The Park in all intents and purposes, is a successful walking sim game, and works as a psychological horror game. It is executed fairly well, despite some flaws and personal issues with it. It delivers some genuinely creepy moments and can be played in one sitting. However, the game does not offer much replay value, other than to be used as a part of halloween game week/day once a year. I bought this at the pre-order price, and for that price, I feel it was well worth that discounted price. Even if I had paid the full price for the game ($12.99 USD) I feel it would have been worth it.

Definately recommended for those who enjoyed The Secret World, or who like games like this and don't want to pay the regular price for Among The sleep.

reviewText:
The Park is something like an atmospheric horror walking simulator. If you despise the idea of a walking simulator, you can stop reading right now. Because that is what you do. There is very little interaction. Instead the narrative is the strong element of this game. You constantly discover new pieces of the story and try to find out what is going on. I won't say more (everything would be a spoiler).

All I can say is that the game gets darker and more intense with every minute. The horror element is not too bad (yes, there are a few jumpscares). And the finale is really nice. I can't say I completely understood what happened in the end (it's a bit open to interpretation). But it left me thinking about the different possibilities, and I spent 20 more minutes in the forum to find out what others think happened. I think this is a good sign, right?

So yeah, I liked it. You just have to ask yourself, are you willing to pay 10 bucks for 90 minutes of entertainment. I am completely fine with the length of this game. But I know many people will not be. So if you are interested, but think 10â‚¬ (13â‚¬ once the release discount expires) is too much, maybe wait for a 50% sale.

Well what do we have here then?

This is a pretty freaky game but not too scary, and i believe it has something to do with The Secret World, but as i havnt played that game i really cant comment on anything related.

But as an outsider you might say, i actually enjoyed playing this game from the start.
Theres not a great deal to it gameplay wise, you cant pick up things, shoot or anything like that not even jump, but the idea of the game is based solely on the story, you basically take a tour around the park and try to piece together whats actually going on, its all about following the story.

As you make your way around, things happen with the odd jump scare and it really gives you that creepy sense like someone is watching you all the time, but i will say it looks really good, the graphics are clean and everything fits in well with the environment and the image there trying to put across.

At first i thought this was going to be like The Stanley Parable, but unfortunately not, from a negative point of view the only things that let the game down is the lack of exploration or puzzles invloved, and the fact its a very short game, i think upto 2hrs, i would have liked to have seen more but thats really the only gripes i have against it.

Overall the story is very interesting and still makes you scratch your head at the end, well worth trying out even if it is short, if you can grab it cheap then go for it, theres no replayability so prolly not worth the full price, but still give it a go if this sounds like your type of game and im pretty sure you will enjoy it.

Faulty's scorecard :-

1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase3) Recommended purchase during a sale
4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

The downward spiral
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=543034003
The Park is a stand alone adventure from FunCom based on their wildly successful MMO, The Secret World, which has a devout following of fans around the globe thanks to the games wonderfully perverse way in which it mixes horror with the supernatural. If you have yet to dive into The Secret World, now that the monthly paywall has been removed, I would highly suggest you do so as still to this day The Secret World remains one of the most unique MMO's I have ever experienced definitely breaking from the standard MMO tropes seen in most MMO's today and it's a game that offers something genuinely unique and exciting that is well worth discovering. Having said that I suppose the first question that might pop into your head is does a person need to have an intimate knowledge of The Secret World to appreciate The Park. Well...yes and no.

As a stand alone adventure for a gamer with no immediate knowledge of The Secret World there is still much to enjoy here but as a player who has dedicated hundreds of hours to the MMO, occasionally diving back in now and then - to put it bluntly - The Park is a treat. Players of The Secret World will immediately recognize the Atlantic Island Theme Park that is situated in the Savage Coast zone, which this time gets to take center stage. In The Secret World it's a dark and foreboding place to visit and not somewhere you would genuinely want to find yourself lost let alone looking for a missing child which is how the story to The Park opens.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=543251039
Taking on the role of a mother, Lorraine, whose child has recently gone missing in The Park your task at the onset is to find and locate the boy. The Park is a a game that is clearly heavily influenced by previous games of this nature such as Gone Home, The Vanishing of Ethan Carter and Dear Esther. It is a solely narrative focused game as you walk around the dilapidated park, a park that was closed down due to some dubious on-goings in the past, uncovering clues in the form of letters, books, newspaper articles and reports that further the story along. There is no inventory so you won't be bothered with collecting things nor will you be required to solve any sort of puzzle along the way. If you go into The Park expecting anything more you will be setting yourself up for disappointment. If like me, you enjoy a good and twisted, and in this games case slightly demented, psychological horror short story that drip feeds you in the beginning before unraveling at a clip as you near completion then yes it's possible this game may be for you. Did I mention that things go bat-â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ crazy towards the end. No! Well prepare yourself for some pretty intense sequences that earn the game its mature rating. If you are the kind of person that is easily disturbed then I would advise you approach this one with caution as some of the elements the story touches on like mental illness might strike a chord.

Without giving too much away I found this story of unrequited love, depression, mental illness and psychosis to be fairly effective and the game does get genuinely harrowing towards the end with just the right amount of jump scares to root it firmly in the realm of horror. One thing that deserves a special mention is the audio design which in a horror game is one of the elements that are  tantamount towards it success. The Park delivers and effective soundscape to go along with the twisted visuals. It will definitely raise the hairs on the back of your neck and for the most part have you constantly looking over your shoulder. Graphically the game looks great although its quite hardware intensive and on my laptop I had to downgrade from 1080p to 900 in order to get a stable 30fps. Granted my system is nearing four years of age now so I suspect that modern cards and machines will have no problem running the game at a full 60fps.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=543012198
The Park had me enthralled from beginning to end even when I kind of deduced which direction the story was headed fairly early on in. That didn't stop me from wanting to continue exploring The Park (which is an absolute chilling delight as you get to enjoy most of the dilapidated rides the park has to offer) and seeing how the game would fully resolve itself was definitely a driving factor. I was even genuinely shocked by the games denouncement. I also loved how FunCom added little visual treats that will be instantly recognizable to any one who has had the pleasure of delving deeply into The Secret World. If FunCom plans on pushing out more of these single player stories based around the MMO; I for one will be delighted. While some may balk at the price for what is essentially a 2 hr experience, if the experience is going to be this fully charged and thrilling then you can count me in. You can most definitely count me in!

reviewText:
I played The Park in an evening over Christmas and it was a great experience, just like being in an interactive movie.

I think that it could of done with some better musical cues to help dramatic scenes pay off, but on the whole it was very well done. In my opinion the ending didn't pay off as well as I think the developers were hoping it would, and it would of been nice to see it handled a little better with (again) better musical backing to try and really increase the tension and atmosphere. I'm sure some people would be happy with the current music arrangement though, it's a matter of personal choice I guess. It works pretty well.

The level design is pretty good and the effects are clever, there are also elements that add more to the backstory if you're interested in that. The story in general I think can be explored quite deeply, the ending has quite a twist which is somewhat predictable I guess, but well done anyway.

Why did I refund the game? Well to put it simply there was no replayability and I completed it in a very short amount of time. If there was a New Game + kind of option so you could play the game again but with a slightly different story, or even mod tools to create your own short horror experience then it would  be a truly great game, but for me it was a little lacking in content. Still happy to give it a good review though as it was a fun experience while it lasted.

reviewText:
The Park is a psychological horror game that is set in the same universe as The Secret World, the latter of which I have never played; thus I'm unsure of any correlation between the two. After playing The Park, I can say that the game can be thoroughly enjoyed without having any knowledge whatsoever of The Secret World. While the developer and publisher, Funcom, have not brought us a plethora of releases, they are known for their quality work. The Park is their first true adventure into the genre of horror, and they take the leap very well.

You play as Lorraine, a mother who has gone back to the Atlantic Island Park to retrieve her son Callum's teddy bear. As you head to the information booth to see if Mr. Bear has been spotted, Callum takes off into the park and it's up to you to chase him down. It doesn't take long for things to take a disturbing twist, as a bright sunny day turns into a dark night where shadows are cast long and the rising mist is at its thickest. Your first of many rides will be taken through the Tunnel of Tales, where you ride in a swan boat and listen to the story of Hansel and Gretel; while this part is quite calm, the game quickly escalates into a full-on escapade of psychological terror driven by both narrative and visuals.

The dark secrets that Lorraine has lurking inside of her go from bad, to awful, to nightmarish as you progress through the story. Take special care to pick up and read any notes and documentation that you may come across, as these help fill in the blanks and enhance the story. The good thing about these notes is that they're never out of the way, and you will be hard pressed to miss any; they're always laid well within the beaten path. The Park itself is extremely linear, and as such there is no way for you to get lost. Even if you somehow cannot manage to find where to go next, you are able to press B (on an Xbox controller) to shout" for Callum

reviewText:
â€œThe Parkâ€ was released on October 27, 2015 by Funcom Games. It is a powerful, narrative-driven psychological horror experience that may be disturbing to some. A review copy of this game was provided directly from Funcomâ€™s Public Relations team.

I remember when The Secret World launched back in 2012 and reading about all the new features the game had to offer. In many ways, the game itself was an experiment at doing something different â€“ at creating a modern-themed MMORPG filled with horror aspects and an open-ended character progression system. The very fact that the game had a strong horror atmosphere to it alone made it different, and despite not having played it much after its launch, I can say I did enjoy what I saw. With this in mind, itâ€™s no wonder that The Park would be something that also shakes the genre up a bit for us.

The Park is set in the early-1980s on the fictional Solomon Island and starts us off with a single mother named Loraine running inside Atlantic Island Park after it closes to chase her son, Callum, who ran in because he left his teddy bear somewhere within. Things start out bright and chipper enough, and even Lorraineâ€™s mood supports this, but on the journey up the escalator that leads into the park, things take a rather dark turn quickly.

Yes, this is a horror game, but no, it doesnâ€™t rely strictly on cheap jump-scares. In fact, at no point in the game are you ever in any sort of immediate danger. The game builds up its tense atmosphere as you go by providing you with an unsettling narrative, dark and foreboding environments, strange situations, and a few creepy encounters that will leave you on the edge of your seat as you go. The game encourages you to explore and take everything in, find notes and documents that provide you with the backstory on the amusement park, and enjoy (or dread) it all at your own pace.

The overall experience is short, yet powerful. Loraine is a character that you can identify with an commensurate with, and perhaps this fact is rather darker than weâ€™d like to admit about ourselves. As Loraine chases after Callum and rides the various rides, a narrative is unraveled that leaves us wondering whatâ€™s really going on. Is this all some strange journey deep into her subconscious in order to deal with some unfathomably-terrible event in her (and Callumâ€™s) past? Is what we see around us meant to be taken quite literally? Or is the truth somewhere between both of these ideas? One thingâ€™s for sure, though: Loraineâ€™s mental state changes as she progresses deeper into the amusement park itself, and this is evidenced by her voice and reactions as she goes. Players can call to Callum as they explore, and at first, both she and Callum seem rather cheerful. Later, though, she becomes more frantic, even angry, and it seems like Callum doesnâ€™t even want to be found.

While playing The Secret World isnâ€™t required to enjoy this game, reading up on its lore and some of its recent tie-in events is a big plus. While The Park provides additional insight into the world of the MMO in regards to the amusement park itself, the MMO may help you further understand the character of Nathaniel Winters, the reason for the parkâ€™s creation (which is discussed in notes found in this game), the presence of a supernatural entity known as The Bogeyman, and explains who the man seen at the beginning (and end) of this game is. Further, understanding the lore of Atlantic Island Park will help formulate ideas on what really happened here, and why the atmosphere transitions from late-afternoon at an operational amusement park to nighttime in a run-down horror fest.

In a future post, I'll go into some spoiler-filled details as to what I really think happened in the game, but for now, I'll only suggest that you take a look at it for yourself.

The game isn't cheap on Steam. Currently, as of this review, it sells for $12.99 and may only take you an hour or two to get through. But, don't look at it as a game to run through so much as an experience to enjoy (like a movie). That may help justify the cost even more.

Ultimately, I highly enjoyed The Park and I think it's a dark adventure that any fans of a psychological horror nature should play. It's fun while it lasts, it's trippy in places, and in the end it leaves you thinking and wanting to know even more. In my opinion, that's the mark of a true success.

reviewText:
Tensely atmospheric, this is a well-told psychological horror story. About the same length as a feature film but more involving (and cheaper), I was gripped from the start. Make no mistake though, this is more story than game. Don't expect a test of skill and reactions, but do expect a test of your nerves.

The main character Lorraine is believably flawed, with much of the exposition being delivered from her remembrances as you explore. It's hard not to be sympathetic as you discover more about her life as she talks. You're guided through your journey by a simple mechanic - right click the mouse and Lorraine will call out for her lost son, giving you audio and visual cues on where to go or what to examine next, with her calls becoming more frantic and scared as the story goes on. You're led to go on several of the titular theme park's attractions, each giving its own unsettling experience.

The game comes bundled with a trial of The Secret World, the free to play MMO in the universe of which the story is set, and some costume items and high level gear to use in that game once you're there. You don't need to know The Secret World to enjoy the story, but those who have played will notice the references dotted throughout The Park.

If you're looking for a chilling story that will leave your heart in your throat, then The Park is for you. If you're looking for something with more longevity and replay value, then this isn't going to satisfy. But for such a small price tag, this is a good buy for horror fans looking for a pretty unique if short experience.

reviewText:
Playing this is like taking a guided tour through a horror story.

What Funcom does well, it does brilliantly.  Despite not being as recognized as is Bioware for story-telling, Funcom excels like no other developer in that category.  Their games tell the best stories.

The Park is a great short story that unfolds before the player from a first-person perspective.  The story will have more meaning to players of Funcom's MMO The Secret World, but the story stands on its own.  Familiarity with TSW's lore is not required to enjoy The Park's story, but there are numerous references that TSW players will likely enjoy.

I would not hesitate to reccomend this game to a friend.  But that reccomendation would have this accompanying caveat - be aware that this is a very short video game.  The length worked well for the story and the pricing was appropriate for the entertainment value.  But as most video games are much longer, it's worth mentioning the short length of The Park so that doesn't become one the playthrough's surprises (those surprises, by the way, work surprisingly well).

Bottom line, this is a good game and a must-buy for any fan of horror stories.

reviewText:
A short, storytelling/exploration game with weirdness and some psychological horror. It's short, indeed, but I think the length is just right: you can take your time and complete it in a single sitting of 2 hours and so it does not overstay its welcome.

I liked the the eerie atmosphere, the choice of a female lead, and the deep, meaningful story about her difficult life with her son - in fact a game focusing on just that and the psychological elements, entirely leaving out the supernatural would have felt a lot more powerful to me. The game looks beautiful and can give you chills at times; the cheap scares are fortunately kept to a minimum.

I didn't like how much the writers are in love with their own setting to the detriment of the player trying to enjoy their story. This game is set in the same world as the MMO The Secret World and as far as I can understand contains plenty of references, winks, nudges and Easter eggs to people in the know. The rest of us, I think, are left with an incomplete picture and are kept in the dark about the forces at work in The Park. This might be why the ending felt so confusing and more than a little lackluster to me. I think you're meant to draw your own conclusions, and it's nice that the game gets you thinking, but in the end it seems that some things either don't add up very well or don't make much sense.

reviewText:
The Park is a mystery adventure psychological horror game, marked with a great atmosphere and a deep and puzzling story.
If this review is too long for you, I suggest you to only read the first paragraph about the game's content and the final verdict at the end.

What is happening in the game:You are a mother of a boy, who lost his beloved teddy bear in an amusement park. As you get there, things become dark and twisted and your son wanders away. You call him back, but he doesn't respond, so you have to go find him yourself. Things start to become weirder and weirder, as you uncover the secrets of the park and, more importantly, your character's twisted mind.
Will you find your son and safely escape the park? Or will you become involved in a much darker experience?

Pros:    The Atmosphere | The developer placed great emphasis on the atmosphere and their hard work is definitely shown when playing the game. Although it's a horror game, it doesn't work on scaring the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ out of you with jumpscares, but rather offers frightening excitement, if that is a term. Sure, there are a few jumpscares, but this is not what The Park aims for.
The Graphics | Combined with the overall atmosphere, the way this amusement park looks and the way it feels you get an amazing experience. Throw in some well-placed fog, rusty Ferris wheel, creepy looking mascot and you get a whole collection of things that make this game play great. Check out the screenshots, as they are actually showing the real situation of this game's appearance (some of them could even make a great desktop background!).
The Story | As explained above, you are a mother of a son who gets lost in this park, but while searching for him, you as a player discover a pretty background of their story, including poor mental condition, depression, death and others. I really got dragged into this story and I felt sorry for both of them. This doesn't happen often to me, so I can safely assume that the writer did a really good job.
The Soundtrack | Every horror game needs a good soundtrack, so this one has one, too! It's some kind of mysterious music, but it raises tension when things are about to go downhill. If you are a person who gets easily scared, you can at some occasions use this to at least slightly prepare for the scary moment.
Achievements | You get those for every ride or discovery in the park, which is great, because it gives you the sense of progress and shows you how far you are into the game.
Bonus Items | This game is happening in the universe of Funcom's other game, The Secret World, so you get some in-game items for that game. I don't play it myself, but I guess it's good for some people.
Cons:    Game's Performance | This game has very high system requirements, which could be a problem for a lot of people. You would expect that this game would run just fine if you meet the recommended" requirements

reviewText:
Summary
Atmospheric but short, The Park tells an exciting story in the small amount of time youâ€™ll spend with it, while leaving you sufficiently creeped out.

This is a spoiler-free review

You begin the game as Lorraine, a mother who has some obvious issues. Your son, Callum, tells you he canâ€™t find Mr. Bear, so you head back into the park, and thus begins your adventure.

The Park is a first-person exploration game. You can add walking simulator on top of that, if you like. As Lorraine, you travel to several different areas of the park, all within a few minutes of each other. Youâ€™ll go on a (creepy) tunnel of love ride, a (creepy) rollercoaster and, of course, (creepy) bumper cars. Along the way, youâ€™ll find notes, which help tell the backstory of the park, several items to examine, see things that arenâ€™t there.

Funcom wasnâ€™t lying when they said that The Park would be a short experience. If you choose not to explore every nook and cranny, and not read all the notes, you can easily complete it in half an hour. I completed it in 45 minutes, and that was with reading every document I came across and examined everything I was able to. (Donâ€™t let my time played fool you; the rest of the time played is letting the game idle to unlock the cards, and a quick replay to get screenshots and video for my achievement guide.)

While a quick experience, itâ€™s a good experience. Theyâ€™ve done an excellent job with the creepiness factor. If youâ€™ve been around horror games (or any horror medium, for that) long enough, you likely wonâ€™t be disturbed or otherwise â€œscaredâ€ of what the game has to offer. The story is entertaining, and really paints a portrait of Lorraine as, well, youâ€™ll find out soon enough.

ProsAtmosphere. The Park is very atmospheric. The amusement park itself is dark and foreboding, rides and equipment are run down and rusty. Some of the ending sequences are very well done, and evoke a feeling of P.T. On that note, thereâ€™s also a Silent Hills-esque feeling that I had when wandering around.

TSW tie-in. If youâ€™ve played The Secret World long enough, youâ€™ll get a few references. Considering The Park is a spin-off of TSW, thatâ€™s to be expected. Thereâ€™s nothing major, but theyâ€™re fun little â€œoh, thatâ€™s interestingâ€ moments.

Acting. For the most part, Lorraine is voiced quite well. Most of her dialog seems natural, and doesnâ€™t feel forced. The further into the story you progress, she sounds more and more desperate and afraid when you use the shout mechanic.

Environmental graphics. The world looks nice. The rusty ferris wheel enshrouded in fog, the rollercoaster that feels like itâ€™s going to fall apart, the statues of Chad the mascot spread throughout the park, everything looks well detailed.

Few jump scares. There are a few jump scares, only a few. They are well placed, donâ€™t seem forced, and they donâ€™t ruin the immersion too much.

ConsCharacter graphics. Lorraine, Callum and the very limited number of other people you meet do not look good. At all. They are passable, but they look like they belong in a game that hasnâ€™t come out this decade.

Shout mechanic. Right-clicking has Lorraine call out for Callum, in a variety of ways. Callum, Callum where you are? Callum, itâ€™s time to go home now! Callum, stay where you are! As the story progresses, itâ€™s interesting to see how her dialog and voice change, but overall, the mechanic is pretty useless. When you use it, it puts a sort of retracting blur effect on items of interest, such as notes. But, considering that the game lacks any puzzles, and everything is presented to you in plain view, it seems out of place.

Very short game. I debated putting this as a con or not. Funcom specifically stated it would be a very short experience, so there should be no excuse for buying the game and being surprised at how quickly youâ€™ll get through it. Itâ€™s a good experience in the short amount of time, but if youâ€™re looking for something to last longer than what your coffee stays hot for, you may want to look elsewhere.

ConclusionThe Park is a fantastic experience. Itâ€™s short, but contains a great deal of story telling and immersion. Itâ€™s interesting to see what happens, and to find out whatâ€™s actually going on. Itâ€™s atmospherically horror, with only a few jump scares, and will certainly entertain you for its duration. At its low price, I consider it good value for money, but as always, your mileage may vary.

Buy, Wait for Sale, Donâ€™t Buy?Buy. Definitely a buy. If you're into non-gory and psychological horror, you won't be disappointed.

If youâ€™re looking to get all the achievements in The Park, they can all be earned in one playthrough, and the majority of them are story related and canâ€™t be missed. Should you need help getting the few that can be skipped, feel free to check out my achievement guide in Steamâ€™s guides section.

reviewText:
First off, The Park is not a bad game, it is just not what you expect.
Sure, the starting atmosphere is spooky and you get a little bit of a haunted feeling. But there is no follow through. You look for your son in a dark theme park that feels scary and every so often you are interupted by some story your protagonist feels the need to share. Not to say the story is bad, it just doesn't support the game - at least not until you reach the end and it all kinda wraps up.
This story telling the game does, negates the whole effect of the dark atmosphere. And soon you will grow complacent in the game. Maybe a jump scare or 2 will startle you, but it never quite feels scary anymore. Quite a shame really.

So in the end; don't buy this game if you are looking for a scary or haunting experience. Don't buy it for the story either. Truly the only reason to recommend this game, is if you are fairly new to horror games and want an easy ride.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SRDEPdlKtb8

The Park is officially designated as a first-person psychological horror adventure. Already I am at odds with the game, as adventure implies exploration, or a puzzle element, and horror implies the need for survival against something that is trying to kill you. The actual exploration in this game is limited to looking for your child, which is the whole point of the game, and there are no puzzles that you have to solve in order to continue. As to horror, the gameplay did nothing to add a feeling of doom, or threat to the character, out side of the story. There is no gameplay, no stealth, no challenge as to how to progress to the next zone, only the need to keep walking and get there. If anything, I would classify this game as a walking simulator with a spooky mentality.

The strongest element is the story, with an immersive environment and a captivating, emotional lead character that draws you into the story. You are pulled into this dark, haunted, confusing theme park as you look for your child. One thing that takes away from the story is that you have to get on the various theme park rides; not because you think your child is on them, or because it is part of the story, but more because you feel you have to in order to collect some lore, and because the developers want you to experience the ride.

The game is short (1-2 hours long) for price they are asking, I feel it needs more than just a really good story. I am conflicted about this game; the story was really good, but the gameplay was atrocious, with little interaction and no adventure element, or choice. For the story, I would recommend you watching a 'Let's Play' from a player you enjoy.

reviewText:
At a first glance, The Park looks like your classic first person horror game that happens to take place in a creepy, abandoned and decrepit amusement park. But it crescendos much more than that.

You play as Lorraine, a single mother who's lost her son, Callum, after visiting the Atlantic Island amusement park.
Upon exiting the park just as closing time arrives, Callum tells her that he misplaced his teddy bear and storms into the amusement park to find it. With darkness quickly approaching and her son missing and ignoring her commands, Lorraine has to enter the park to find him, while strange things slowly begin to occur in the once friendly location.

The story is a bit hit and miss, starting out weak but improving near the end of the game. As you explores the park at night and rides its various innocent yet menacing rides, the plot develops through Lorraine's monologue, which reveal her history and search for answers, and documents that are strewn about the park that reveal its dark past. Funcom have made no secret of the influence from games like Gone Home and The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, and the comparisons come almost instantly as you begin walking around the troubled theme park.

It's also more involved than your average title, as you can ride the rides in the park (a Ferris wheel, rollercoaster, and the like), and look around at your surroundings while doing so. Controls are at a minimum with the ability to move and interact with any items, but I have to say I liked the inclusion of a run mechanic. It makes sense in this context â€“ youâ€™re in freaky hellscape of a park trying to find your son, after all â€“ but it means that moving between sections doesnâ€™t feel like a chore. The Park also uses call mechanic with the right mouse button that not only helps guide you to your next objective, but works brilliantly in the context of the game. Hearing Lorraine call out to Callum with increasing worry and panic is expertly done, as are the responses the player gets. It was these responses along with the swirling visual markers that ensured I knew where I was supposed to be going, although it wasnâ€™t fool proof. There were a few moments where I had to wander around before I was able to get back on the right path, but I didnâ€™t find it too frustrating or time-consuming, thankfully. There's also a decent amount of lore-building involved, and not just because of the Lovecraftian themes that are intertwined with the Funcom-verse. I actually enjoyed reading about various incidents at the park, and how they involve the cast although I did have an issue with some of the the scattered pages and documents you can find off the beaten path, detailing some of the gameâ€™s backstory. It seems unfortunate that some of them are nearly unreadable, as the font on these are tiny and blurry. A clearer font, zoom button or a subtitle option would have been an alternative, but as the game lacks it, unless you strain your eyes to read, youâ€™ll be missing out on some of the backstory that ties it to Funcomâ€™s other game, The Secret World.

The strongest part however is the end of the game, which is both fantastic and unfortunate, as itâ€™s such a strong and beautifully creepy finish that is way more terrifying compared to the rest of the experience. If only the gameâ€™s setting and story would have more like the last part of the game, it would have been a much more horrifying game.
Overall, The Park is a well crafted narrative-driven adventure game, but there really is no reason to return once youâ€™ve left The Park unless you want to get those missable achievements or analyse the letters and items again to figure out more of the backstory. However, if you want something a little different this Halloween, play this with the headphones on and the lights off.

reviewText:
OK. So to be completely clear, I have been playing The Secret World since launch, and bought three copies of this game within 10 minutes of it's availability. So this review is not exactly coming from an unbiased perspective.

To start with the mechanics, it was nice and simple. Movement plus three buttons. The right-mouse-click to call for Callum worked well both as a story device and a mechanic to point you to things, however I did feel that it was a little hard to know if you'd missed something sometimes. I would occassionally find myself using it several times, just to make sure I hadn't missed anything. The only other thing I would say about this is that the scraps of paper found in the game were very hard to read. I had to move to about half distance away from my monitor to have any chance of reading it at all.

Moving onto the world. If Funcom proved one thing with The Secret World (they proved lots more than one thing), then it is that they can make a beautiful world to play in. With three years and a different game engine, the awesomeness has only gotten better. I was playing with max graphics settings, and it was really awesome. It wasn't just the visuals though. The audio environment created by Simon Poole was brilliant. I regularly found myself spinning around to look for something I thought was creeping up behind me. I knew that there was nothing there, but I thought there was enough to look. AKA: Brilliant. I remember seeing one instance of a spark passing through a solid wall, but beyond that, I felt it was flawless.

Lastly, the story. I don't want to say too much here, because spoilers. However, I finished the games with several questions. On the most over-arching scale, I found myself questioning which parts were the dark reality of the park, and which were Lorraine's 'reality'. To be clear, I think this is a good thing. I'm also not sure of the whole story of Steve, but I suspect that's because I missed something, though it does also get looked at in The Secret World.

Overall, I loved the game. I had no problem with the story, way less than no problem with the world, and only a couple of issues the mechanics. I will be playing again, no question asked. Would totally recommend this for others.

reviewText:
The Park is a horrifying atmospheric adventure game in the same vain of The Vanishing of Ethan Carter and Gone Home.  But I already knew that. What surprised me was the last act of the game when it turned into PT.  I was very pleasantly surprised and probably the most creeped out by that turn of events.

I recommend picking up everything you can find.  Notes, photos, articles, the like as that is where the background to the strange going ons of the park is found.  Especially in the last part, a few times, trust me.

It stands on its own but if you have played The Secret World you will notice people, places, and events referenced from there like familar old ghostly friends. I'm one of those who had so it made it fun to get mentions to certain motels and diners that feature in TSW. However if you are going in blind it shouldn't be to spoilerific if you want to play TSW after and there is enough background that you will get the jist of the park even if you don't.

reviewText:
in July 2012, FunCom released an MMO called The Secret World. set in the modern day with an occult/conspiracy/horror theme, it'd turn out to be the best-written MMO and one of the best-written and best-acted games of all time. with a strong setting and stronger characters, TSW was primed for popularity among an unfortunately small subset of MMO players: those who wanted to really care about the setting they were in.

one of the areas you'd encounter within a few hours of your picking up the game was the park. it was one of the earliest serious puzzle areas of the game, but beyond that, it was a terrifying environment, both in terms of how it looked and the threats that roamed around it. the Park in TSW was one of the great pieces of level design of all time--comparable to and maybe better than the haunted house in Bloodlines.

enter The Park. The Park is set in TSW's Park, redesigned for a first-person narrative game. there are no challenges in The Park: it's a walkthrough game, just a story being told. it does, however, start with one of the best mechanics I've ever seen in a horror game: right at the outset, you get the ability to shout to find your next objective. giving the player the option to scream and give away their position in a horror game is one of the best ideas I've ever seen. control your own nightmare; make yourserlf feel exposed.

The Park itself (stop reading now if you don't want any inkling of the story) is about a normal person (not a TSW-style chosen of Gaia...at first) wandering the haunted park in search of her son. the plot unfolds through one-page journal entries you find and monologues from the main character. early on in the 90-120 minute experience, it comes clear that the story is really about being a mother, being a single parent, and the stresses and resentments that develop therewith. I won't explicitly spoil how it all works out, but for the TSW fans out there, know that the last scene is a wonderful TSW cameo.

in the end, The Park works. to someone unfamiliar with TSW, it might feel like an Amnesia-esque horror game, minus any threats; to someone who does know TSW, the hooks to Kingsmouth and the TSW setting in general will probably be the most interesting bits. it's short, it's cheap, and it'll either intrigue you about an MMO you should try or excite you about an MMO you have tried. what's to lose?

reviewText:
I hate horror games.

Okay, okay, I'll admit it.  I don't hate them, I'm just too much of a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ to play them myself.  But for The Park, I grew some balls and sat down in the dark for a good scare.

I'm also going to admit that I'm cheap.  Normally, I regret pretty much anything I spend money on.  However, I definitely do not regret this game.

The atmosphere was the BEST part of this game.  I scare easily, and there were some jumpscares that got me of course, but it wasn't just that.  The game wasn't particularly scary; I've seen worse.  It was extremely unsettling.  It took the time to get under your skin and stick with you.  That, in my opinion, is MUCH more effective than any jumpscare.  I felt on edge even after the game ended for a while afterwards.

The voice acting was surprisingly great.  I didn't run into any glitches.  Like I said, I was completely immersed in the atmosphere of the park.  The story was surprisingly good; a lot of it left me thinking.  I ended up recommending the game to some friends just so I could have other people to discuss the story of the game with.  Overall, I find that The Park was worth my money.  It really packs a punch for the short game that it is.

reviewText: The Walking Simulator genre is a loved & hated phenomenon in gaming. The haters claim they're not really games if for example you can't die, if there's no or limited interaction or puzzles, or if the game is short. But games comes in all shapes & sizes. If they're distributed on gaming platforms, we may as well call them games, and then put a fitting sub category to it. I mean I don't consider all films films just because they were shot on film, some are actually pure garbage, but hey.\nI enjoyed this little game for it's story & atmosphere, which resonated strongly with me. But it won't with everyone. I still think it is an unusual story & themes seldom touched upon baked into a classic haunted house type of frame. I applaud the makers for being so brave, & I think stories like this needs to be told more.That is it's strong point. reviewText:
While the game is short and can be completed in less than 2 hours, the story is interesting and the world is very immersive, eerie, and haunting. It's a first person experience game much like Dear Esther and Gone Home or even the Stanley Parable. The game uses a lot of flavor text that the player can find that adds to the background story of the park. This adds to the horror elements which are well done with plenty of scares throughout.

That being said the level of interactivity you have with the world is fairly limited although calling out to your son makes for an interesting mechanic. Admittedly, I myself didn't use this mechanic for about the last half of the game as frequently as I did at first. The length was only a con in my opinion due to it leaving me wanting more and curious about The Secret World.

I recommend this title to anyone who enjoys an immersive, eerie, paranormal story with a good number of scares.

reviewText:
The park is a decent if short game.
I'll admit that most of the jumpscares caught me off guard especially when I was expecting them because there were a lot of spots where you know they would show up and they did.
This is one of those walkabout games where you will spend alot of your time walking and exploring the park as you move from one ride to the next whilst looking for your wayward son.


Spoilers ahead:
My main problem with this game however is it's story.  You start off thinking it's going to be a horror game where you unravel the mystery of what's going on at the park via notes and incident reports.  So at first glance it seems to be a story about how the proprietor of the park purchased the land from a man who commited great atrocites.  The idea being that the park was going to try to be something positive in what would have been a very negative zone.  As you progress through the park and read various documents you learn that there have been various deaths throughout the years starting way back when it was under construction and still occuring even after the park opened it's doors.
You learn that the proprieter actually had an ulterior motive for setting up the park and wasn't as altruistic as he first seemed.  Eventually the park gets shut down by health inspectors and the proprietor retreates to the horror house where his machine was.

but around the third act the game decides to forget all that and switch gears to become about the protagonist and her mindset, trying for a twist that you would have already saw coming from a mile away if you payed the slightest attention to her dialogue.

All i'm going to say as much as I liked the game the last bit of it was the weakest.  I really wish they stuck it out with the regular horror aspect and had us confront whatever was controlling the park.

End spoilers.

other than that though.  It's a real neat tie-in game to an mmo. that knows how to build atmospere and give a general sense of unease even though there are times you can tell when there is going to be a jumpscare well before it happens.

reviewText:
This is time writing any form of a review on Steam but I enjoyed recording this game so much that it felt warranted.

My friend and I run a Youtube channel and I saw this on Steam about a month ago and decided to preorder it. We're also recording The Coma and figured we'd squeeze it into our recording schedule.

It completely took over our schedule for today.

We wound up going through the entire game in one sitting...which leads me to my two only qualms with the game. While I absolutely loved the game, calling it a game is a little misleading. While you control Lorraine and have mild interactions with the world it's definetely more akin to a walking simulator with a great back story. And while the story is great, it does run short. The quote from Funcom is between 1-2 hours and we beat it in about 80 mins so they're pretty spot on. Some people may gripe about the price compared to the amount of time but seeing as a movie ticket costs $12 then it's not a huge deal(Especially since a ton of site have this on sale already)

Those points aside we were completely transfixed with the story and the setting. The game looks rock solid, the voice acting from Lorraine was amazing and the story left me wanting more. Without ruining it I will say that the end will leave you with more questions than answers but all in all it's a damned solid experience and I would recommend it.

reviewText:
Let be break this down for you as simple as possible.

What FunCom has done here is create something that many TSW players were looking for in game when visiting the amusement park while questing.  They had created this visually fantastic area filled with mystery and intrigue.  All I could think about when running that series of quests is that I wanted a better, more in depth look at the park, and this game delivers the content I was looking for.

If you have not played through the story in The Secret World, much of this game will seem linear and boring.  It expands on what we learn and gives us another taste of the darkness that stood out in my first playthrough.  As TSW is broken up into sections and areas, you have to leave that section to further advance your character.  Having a short reprise, for me at least, was a nice throwback.  If they make more games like this, based on the other sections of the game, I will probably buy them as well.

I honestly think this is a good start in a new direction for FunCom, and that more of these games, with larger and further developed storylines will be worth the playtime.

I feel like they made this game for me.  Thank you FunCom.

reviewText:
I liked this game and it is thrilling to experience how developers still manage to make good stories. We see the history through the protagonists eyes. Lorraine lost her son a the amusement park and starts searching after him. In the coming sequences we see odd things, experience paranormal things and the context is puzzling. The last scene is surely the climax of the whole story, Lorraines story.

As I see it she was not only depressed but seems to have a traumatic story. Just think, early attachment problems, a mother who rejects her and accusing her for having abandoned her by running away with the father. Then father is gone and her relatives dont want to share the insurance amount with her. There she stands alone before she meets a man and happiness is back in her life. But not for so long. The man dies and she becomes a single mother with a low-paId job. She also had post-partum depression for which she also was hospitalized and medicated for. I interpret the park as the conscious level and the grottos and the stairs in the last part as the sub-consciuos levels. As she walk through the rooms several times she relives the trauma again and again. Slowly the repressed memories comes to a consciuos level but she actively tries to repress them. The final scene where she stabs her son seems to me to be a try to get rid of the alien part of the self. I think that her son is in custody and that Lorraine seems to be psychotic.

Overall I liked the game as mentioned earlier. There are some cons though. Gameplay is a little bad mechanised and there should have been icons popping up when reading a note and alike. Walking is too slow and I finished the game by running. The game is a little too short and could have been longer.

I recommend this game for those who fancy psycology and ambient soundtrack.

reviewText:
Note: This review is after my first play through of the game

I originally saw trailers for The Park months before it came out and once it became available to pre-order on Steam, I bought it; there was the advantage that it was also on sale but this was my first ever pre-order on Steam and I am happy to say, I was not in any way disappointed.

To be clear, the game tells you it is a narrative driven game, much like games from Tell Tale or the game Gone Home, this means actions are limited in place of following/taking part in the story. So to those who expect anything else, you only have yourself to blame.

I really enjoyed this game, the atmosphere is immersive as it blends a perfect mix of visuals and audio to keep you tense and constantly pressing the right mouse button. The game itself is short but that is not neccessarily a terrible thing, games do not need to be long they only need to be entertaining and padding them out with repetitive game play often only takes away from the experience.
If you are new to horror, this may not be a bad choice, the game is very easy to get into and easier to get lost in.

Edit: I am seeing a lot of reviews complaining about the game being a narrative driven game. I am not sure why because the game, the trailer, the developers all said it is a narrative driven game. People had the same complaints about Gone Home and the Vanishing of Ethan Carter but you never hear people complain about about any other game like this It didn't say it was twin-stick shooter" or "it didn't say it was a third person shooter"
date: so why should a game have to apologize for what it is?\nIf you don't like narrative driven games

reviewText:
The Park is a short bite sized nugget of terror. Giving you a glimpse into madness itself using the whimsy and charm of an amusement park from hell. You will guide a young mother as she searches for her son Callum. Along the way you begin to unravel the mystery of the park and learn more about Lorraine. While I enjoyed the game cinematically, there are times the game takes your out of the action and lets you just watch. Which is fine but I never felt like I was in any real danger. For the most part The Park does rely on jump scares to get you. There are moments of intensity and dread but low on the actual scare factor.(Atleast for me) As for the story of The Park, to really understand it or enjoy it is a matter of interpretation and plenty of reading. Scraps of paper and notes are strewn about the game and give you a glimpse into the backstory of the world. By the end though you are still left with more questions then answers. I think this was done purposefully though. Something that buyers should beware is that the game does have some glitches. The game crashed once on initial start up and I had to restart after Callum got scared of escalators and prevented me from moving further. Despite these minor hiccups, I did really enjoy the somber story of The Park. The ending is quite shocking and leaves you with your mouth open. The only gripe I have is that certain pieces of backstory are connected to another game. Which I haven't played. The connected stories are rather loose and doesn't necessarily prevent you from enjoying The Park but those looking to really dig into the lore and story will need to venture further onto message boards and wikis. In all it is a well defined story and had me intrigued to the very last minute.

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/gGkw71VOEhA
I hope you enjoy!
Martyr

reviewText:
As a player who decides what games to buy based on the reviews of the certain game, it's my duty to write a complete review about any game i finish, so here is my review:

THE PARK:

This game is a first person, short, psychological horror, story based walking simulator where you are a mother Lorraine who searches her son Callum throughout the Park, while learning all it's dirty secrets.

In this game there is no map, except throughout the Park, and you don't have choices in where you can go, you just go straight ahead and ride the Park's attractions while reading notes while scrolling through the Prak.

Before i proceed with the Pros and Cons i would like to remind you that the following are my personal preferences and may differ for any individual who plays the game.

PROS:
+The story was unique
+Whilst a horror game, it isn't always based on scaring you, more like making you think
+The world is well designed
+The playthrough is pretty simple for new players and experienced ones to enjoy
+It has some jumpscares but as many as tehre should be

CONS:
-It had some fps drops and lags in-game
-The characters were bad designed (even though it doesn't really matter in-game)
-It was short, like 2 hours playthrough short

SUGGESTIONS FOR DEVELOPERS:
-Drop the price a bit, 13â‚¬ is too much for a game where no one would play more than 3 hours tops
-If you decide to keep the price, make some free expansion parks so that we could experience more Park attractions
-Make more games like this, this one was awesome

SUGGESTIONS FOR CUSTOMERS:
-Buy it on sale, even though it is worth 13â‚¬
-Enjoy the full of it in a dark room with your headphones on, trust me, it won't be scary at all ;)
-Don't worry about getting all the achievements, almost all of them will be obtained while playing the story

TL;DR
This game is really good and i recomend it to anyone who is into Horror games that are not based on the actual horror but on a good frightening story

9/10 keep on Funcom!!!!

Some people say it was too short. I strongly disagree. The developers made it clear from the trailer just a few weeks ago it would be short and focus on the story, rather than the length of the game. reviewText:
An interesting game. I mostly grabbed this because I am a fan of The Secret World MMO, and this game is set within that universe. I appreciated the deeper insight into the the park and its denizens.

This is less of a game than an interactive short story... and by interactive, you're really just picking things up and examining them. There is no combat or puzzle solving or any other aspects of a traditional computer game that you may be expecting.

That aside, it was fairly creepy... especially with headphones on so you can hear the nuances of the sound effects. It would have been much creepier in the dark, but the sun was still up when I decided to try it out.

The only bad things I have to say about it are that it is short (finished it in less than 2 hours) and towards the end, there are elements that repeat over and over. While I know that is there to elicit a psychological effect, I started to get bored of the repetitiveness of it. I also felt the ending was a bit lackluster, but fitting. With the buildup, I guess I was expecting something more dramatic. I was also hoping for more paranormal elements, given the tie in with The Secret World.

Anyway, for the price, this game is worth playing if you're a fan of the psychological horror genre, or you're a fan or player of The Secret World MMO. Just try to play it in the dark with headphones on. :)

I though the Park was an intresting experinece. First of all, this isn't a game, its more of an interactive story like Heavy Rain but with a linear story.

The atmosphere established quickly is quite eerie and carries the theme of the abandoned park nicely. It was great to hear the creaking of all the old amusement rides.

Story: It was quite short but I was expecting that so I wasn't too disapointed. Plotwise its quite obvious whats going to happen, but finding out the backstory of the main character was really cool and I enjoyed that. Finding all the notes was really cool, and reading them was really intresting.

Gameplay: Quite limited in what you can do, but thats okay as it drives you through the story quickly. What you can do is walk around, call out Calum and read notes.

Personal Experience: The characters of the villans were intresting, would have loved to see Chad explored more thourghly. I was a bit disapointed that they didn't explore the park in more detail, or add little things like having the Father fall off the Ferris Wheel when you got to the top or something like that. I love the sound in the game and overall I enhjoyed the experience.

Recommend this for people who don't mind a short experince that is intresting and unique in setting.

reviewText:
To give my personal review of this game, I will answer a few questions the reader might have in mind.

1. Is this actually a game?
If you, like me, consider that an interactive software needs some sort of obstacles, adversity, or problem solving to be considered a game, then no, it is not a game. The Park won't ask you to solve any puzzle, nor will it ever hide from you the means to progress, and there is no conditions for failure.

2. Is it an enjoyable experience?
For me, it was.

3. What are the game's strengths?
While the story of this game is not the most original (especially if you are already familiar with Salomon Island), it still keeps you interested, and wanting to discover more as you go. Another strength is in the game's ambiance, carefully and successfully crafted mainly through carefully used sound effects and lighting.

4. Any blatant flaw?
A few technical flaws, most notably during the first quarter of the game, can be a little bit distracting. I experienced stuttering during the first part, and noticed what I would call a lack of polish during the same part. Thankfully, once I walked into the actual park, I did not notice any of that anymore.

5. Is it worth the price?
If your personal equation is based on a time versus money" reasoning

reviewText:
Horror games have a special place in the pit of all consuming darkness that is my heart, and psychological horror games have an even more special place. Now, let's break this down.

The game follows a depressed mother looking for her lost child in a really creepy amusement park named Atlantic something. Moving on, the game soon takes a turn for the worst when the sky darkens and you wander around with this woman talking to you, telling the most tragic (but very well written) story about her life, her contradicting views on Callum, her son, and some conversation between her and a skinny, well dressed Oogie Boogie from The Nightmare Before Christmas (if you don't know what I'm talking about please re-evaluate your entire life). The game seems to follow the story of Hansel and Gretel (follow the path and when you see the swan boat ride, ride it to get an achievement and a man retelling the story). References to the tale are mentioned here and there.

If you've played Outlast before (which I reccomend HIGHLY if you haven't), then you know what jumpscare and gore horror is. This is not that. I'm not saying there's not blood and bodies in this game, but the numbers, compared to Outlast, are few; however, this game is scary, but more psychologically.

Pros:
-fantastic story
-creepy atmosphere
-sp00ky soundtrack

Cons:
The only con I have about this game is that it's really short. You can finish it within an hour, which sucked because I really got into the story.

8.5/10

Hasta la vista, baby

-Citrus

reviewText:
PROS:
The voice acting was well done, and they introduced an interesting new gameplay mechanic of calling out, which changes as the game progresses. (See the cons list for the flip side of this.)
The creepy feeling of mental instability without just relying on jump scares to cause the player to question the environment.
Interesting visual effects.
CONS:
Your journey into insanity is abruptly interrupted two or three times (in this under an hour game) just when you think your character is on the brink with normal toned dialogue. It just sucks you right out of the mood. A short example: Wildly tripping out on drugs and seeing things, passing out, and then waking up and having a fairly casual conversation in narrative mode as if nothing just happened.
If you watched the trailer, you know about 20% of the potentially scary content of the game.
Very, very short game. Maybe 50 minutes. Almost no real replay-ability. (FYI. You have to idle the game for an extra 2 1/2 hours just to get the trading card.)
A fairly abrupt ending leaves you feeling fairly unsatisfied.

In short, this is an entertaining story of a woman with mental issues walking toward insanity trying to find her wildly disobedient son. I think me saying anything more would spoil it.

Verdict:
For a discounted price (-50% off, or about $6) this is worth checking out, even if painfully short and a bit flawed regarding the smoothness of its narration and timing of dialogue.

7 out of 10

reviewText:
The Park isn't a game in the strictist sense. In terms of what you actually do as a player your only options are to shout out for the protagonists son and to toggle between run and walk. The primary interactive elements come in the form of interactable documents within the world which you can choose to examine on discovery as well as a few rides which you may choose to ride upon or not.

However what the game lacks for in terms of direct gameplay it makes up for in atomosphere. The developer clearly was hoping to capture the creepy factor of an abandoned amusement park, in this they have largely been successful. The game is not overly reliant upon jump scares and rather focuses on the pyschological horror of a protagonist who clearly has deep seated mental issues.

The storytelling is excellent, going in I expected the plot to be fairly straight forward as Lorraine (The player character) became increasing panicked to get her son back. Without spoiling anything I can say that she is a far more complex character and the plot goes to some very dark places.

Overrall the game is an excellent horror experience with quality voice acting, writing and world building. However it lacks much interactivity and is decidedly short. The side information found through documents is also likely to be less interesting to those who aren't invested in the wider The Secret World universe.

I pre-ordered The Park awhile back but never got around to downloading it, but I was long overdue for â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ myself so, you know, why not. Let me begin by saying while I'm not exactly the most steel-balled human being on this earth, I'm not a regular at Weenie Hut Jrs either.

At a glance (low settings, laptops are for idiots, read: me) graphics are looking really good, even on the lowest setting. I peeked over at ultra now and then and there wasn't a HUGE visible difference, but it's all looking really good. My only big wtf moment so far was the protagonist's mom pants.

Scare factor sets in pretty early. If static, whispered voices, and â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ kids are pros in your gaming experience, congratulations, this game is for you. If you don't hate children, you probably will about ten minutes in.

Bonus vague commentary: Well, I've definitely never heard this version of Hansel and Gretel before.

Great graphics, horrifying atmosphere, the dialogue can be a little poetic and out of place at first but after awhile you're kind of going '/oh/' with realization. Please note I haven't actually finished the game, but I went into this entirely blind and I'm pretty pleased so far. I'm about 80% in (I think) and am ready to â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ punch any amusement park mascot for the rest of my life.

reviewText:
I want to get this out... I am going to RECOMMEND this game with some conditions.   If you get it on sale, or if you just want to support Funcom then it is recommended.   It is well put together.   It is extremely short, and it is very much on rails.   I don't think the decisions I made in the game really had much of a game factor.   It is more like playing a twisted movie (and yes it is twisted) where your actions determine when the movie progresses to the next part.

As a developer myself this felt very much like a nifty tech demo for the Unreal Engine, almost like Funcom was messing with it to learn all the ins and outs and see where they could push it.

I am a big fan of The Secret World, and this does feel like something out of that game though this Atlantic Island Park is laid out a lot different than the area in The Secret World.   This area is much bigger.

I completed this so fast I am still waiting on the third card to drop.   I actually finished it in about and hour to an hour and a half.   It is far too short in my mind, and it didn't feel like a game as much as an interactive movie, where reaching certain points is like clicking the button to advance to the next scene.

You do get some cool items for your Secret World account for buying this so that does make it worth something too.

Overall... I'll give it a YES, but be warned it is VERY short.   It may be the shortest game I personally have ever played.

reviewText: What can I say about The Park...? Well, it was a psychological thrill ride from start to finish; many reviews you'll see claim the game can be finished in an hour, or even half an hour if you rush and don't attempt to unravel the mystery. That's part of the fun, though; I played the game with my boyfriend at my side, and we both watched on as the story of the regretful mother began to unfold. The scenery is well-designed and eerie, the voice acting is especially disconcerting at times, and everything about the game came together so nicely to tell the story. Fans of The Secret World will recognize the location, but even without the background knowledge from that game one can enjoy the story as it develops. What, exactly, is happening at Atlantic Island Park? You'll have to play to find out. Some have argued the cost is too high for the length of the game, but with everything you get I'd say it is well worth it.

So, I completed the park yesterday and I must say I was impressed!

I'm not really a fan of the horror genre generally but I was drawn to The Park from the interesting artwork on the steam thumbnail and was completely sold when I watched the trailer.

Graphically the game was very good, obviously not AAA graphics but a very respectable effort and utilised in some excellent ways, the rides were very creepy looking and it was the subtle details that really added to the atmosphere.

reviewText:
The Park is a superb horror game. It's personal and psychological, sure there are jump scares but the deeper you get into the game the more you begin to dread the things you suspect rather than the external threats. People who have played The Secret World will get more out of the story than newcomers, but the game should be understandable for all, and hopefully some newcomers to the setting will be drawn into the deeper story of the MMO.
