reviewText:
I don't know if I should recommend this or not. Though it can be very scary at times, I just don't the fact that they say it is very focused on storytelling, which it was not. I only got a little bit out of the story and expected everything to wrap up at the end, but it doesn't. What's the dark secret of the park they want you to discover? I don't know. I just didn't get it.

The game's mechanics are pretty simple. You walk, you find notes, you read them, you continue walking. You can call for your son (whose name was so weird I can't seem to remember it) by right clicking, and I thought that was a pretty neat idea. But...

WARNING: THE FOLLOWING CONTAINS SPOILERS.

In the end it's pointless because you kill him by stabbing him with a halloweenpumpkin carving knife in the head? I don't know.

This game is VERY obviously inspired by Five nights at Freddy's. I mean you can't get any closer. There's something that's basically like the bit of '87, but here it's a guy who worked there and they had to wear mascot suits (SOUND FAMILIAR?) who killed a bunch of teenagers  for no real reason in 1979. I guess they were also going for something similar to FNaF where people speculate and theorise about it and the other incidents mentioned in newspapers and notes you find in the game, but really, they're just too vague and not too interesting. There was something going on about a guy who needs energy for a machine that makes eternal life possible or something like that, but they never really explained that. There was also a note by someone saying his old school friend who was working in the park as one of those mascots got really weird and wanted to be called chad (the name of the mascot) from then on and never wanted to get out of the suit. Now, this is a really interesting idea. But it REALLY doesn't work. Guess why? It's never mentioned again. EVER.


--SPOILERS OVER--

In the end, The Park is one of those games you play once, get kind of scared, and then never play again except for a let's play or to try harder to get the story this time.

6/10

reviewText:
We got our hands on Funcomâ€™s new psychological horror game The Park to see how a game that cites Gone Home and Dear Esther as inspirations. Personally, I thought there was also quite a large Silent Hill 2 influence in there as well.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T2GmK-kq58A

The whole game takes place in an amusement park on the premise that your son, Callum, has lost his teddy bear. While you head over to talk to the guy behind the counter, you hear Callum (at least we assume itâ€™s Callum) running behind you and into the park. This begins your journey into the park and into insanity.

As we mentioned, youâ€™re a mother to a small boy (Lorraine) and you have to look for Callum by calling out his name (which provides some clues and also some responses from him) and riding on the rides in the park. Thereâ€™s not really much you can do while youâ€™re on the rides, but we would suggest looking around as much as you can. This is where you end up seeing things and where the sound design comes into its own, but more on that later.

There isnâ€™t really any other mechanics apart from that. Itâ€™s more of a psychological experience / experiment rather than a game. But sometimes itâ€™s better that way without having to solve puzzles to progress the storyline. Itâ€™s what made Slender one of the biggest horror game franchises in the past.

Graphically we were getting around 30 fps on average, but that improved later in the game to 60. It may have been something running in the background. It looks pretty nice and the park seems quite well designed for a horror setting. The pristine look soon vanishing for an abandoned look once you get to the top of the entrance. The game requires a level of darkness to really appreciate, but at times it can be a bit tricky to see if you use their recommended settings. The game doesnâ€™t have much in the way of characters, but every now and again you might view Lorraine (the protagonist) in a 3rd person view or Chad The Chipmunk with his evil looking red eyes.

Chad, it seems, is one of those park mascots that you normally get in large amusement parks to entertain the guests. It soom becomes apparent, however, that not everything is right with Chad. Someone has scrawled a poem on his statue and your first encounter with him leaves you feeling incredibly uneasy. Thereâ€™s more to the Chad story, but we donâ€™t want to give away any spoilers here.

The sound design in The Park really work well to create the atmosphere of an abandoned amusement park and the way sounds come and go as you walk around or ride the rides can make you pretty tense. The banging and splashing on the swan ride really made me feel uneasy. The voice acting isnâ€™t too bad and is fairly believable as Lorraine becomes ever increasingly frantic in her hunt for Callum. There are times when your ability to call out is removed, but thatâ€™s generally only on the rides.

Itâ€™s nice to have a horror game that isnâ€™t all about jump scares. Yes, there are one or two in the game, but theyâ€™re not the be-all-end-all of things. The fear comes from that sense of thinking something is going to happen soon. Is there something hiding behind that rock? Will that teddy bear suddenly move?â€¦ WHAT THE HELL WAS THAT?! NOPE! NOPE! NOPE! If played properly with the lights low and headphones on with the volume up, this game can (and probably will) put the willies up you. It gets even more sinister as you learn about the park itself and Chadâ€¦ Damn you, Chadâ€¦ The ice-sculpting chipmunkâ€¦

The game is only a short one. Its story it told in the space of one to two hours and is a great late-night romp for anyone looking for something a bit different to whatâ€™s currently going around. As an added bonus, if you also play Funcomâ€™s The Secret World, this game will unlock some special items in that game for you (imagine running around as a giant killer chipmunkâ€¦ Youâ€™re welcome).

Overall, itâ€™s well worth a look and one that should do well for Halloween. If you do play The Secret World, then itâ€™s a no brainer to get this one. Otherwise, you can still grab this, turn out the lights, turn up the volume and have yourself a scary evening.

reviewText:
Amazing, A+, fingers crossed Funcom continues to make this sort of thing until they run out of ideas. Which is hopefully never.

I would say the Park is like an interactive movie--playtime is about the length of one, you can't die, and there's no quicktime or combat. You explore a horrifying amusement park while trying to find your child, and witness everything fall apart in something more immersive than a movie would be. If you prefer challenging content this probably won't be your cup of tea, but if you like a terrifying atmosphere and a dark horror story, I highly recommend checking it out.

This game deals with depression (and how terribly it was handled in the 80s), and a pretty dark side of parenthood. There are also a few bright flashes on the rollercoaster, though nowhere near as bad as the trailer--they seemed pretty well spaced out, as I recall. Do exercise caution if any of these might be harmful or upsetting.

The Park is tied in with the MMO The Secret World--it takes place in a location that exists in TSW and drops a few names, but in no way does it require having played TSW first. It's perfectly self-contained, and you won't lose any of the horror if you only play the Park. However, I do recommend at least taking advantage of the one-week trial this game gives you, because TSW has similarly strong story and atmosphere and the majority can be played solo if you so choose. It'll also give you reason to re-play the Park after you finish Solomon Island, to see what extra context you recognize.

All in all, the Park is high on atmosphere, with a few jump scares and a lot of psychological horror that gets steadily heavier as you near the end.

reviewText:
It's short.  That's not a complaint, that's just re-stating what the developers said all along, since I've seen many people complaining about it.  And for those complaining about the cost, think of the it as the price of admission to a movie.  It lasts about as long as a long movie, and tells a good story that you get to participate in, which some people do in the theaters; but in this case, you are supposed to.

I really enjoyed the game.  I took it slow and participated in the ambiance.  That's what makes this an engrossing game.  I am slightly biased, as the sinister carnival scenario is my favorite theme (which is why I really like the amusement park area in Secret World).

If you are looking for a fast paced game, skip this one.  It is intentionally slow paced.  It is linear, but that is necessary to make sure the story unfolds as it should, and doesn't detract from the game; it didn't feel forced to me.

I liked the fact that it was psychological horror, and not just full of jump scares (there were almost no jump scares, but I'm not telling where the couple that are there are located...).

I did like the ending as it was, to me, somewhat ambiguous, leaving a lot of room to think about the game and the journey there instead of having things spoon fed to me.

It's a lovely homage to Lovecraft, which is also another of my favorites.  There was obvious influence from Silent Hill; again one of my favorites.  So all in all a nice mixup of goodness.

The only real complaint I have is that Lorraine's wrists really creep me out; the model bends all wrong.  :)

I would like to see more stories presented this way.  No guns or fights; just good story telling.

Kudos to Funcom for stepping outside the mold.

It is definitely worth taking a trip through.

This game hits it out of THE PARKClick for Full Detailed Review[gonewiththewin.com]
Click for gameplay video and summary

The Park. Gets it right. It's first and foremost a twisted and disturbing story. A haunting tale befit any campfire story telling time. It is dressed up in well done art design, and a fantastic nightmarish setting of an evil mysterious theme park at night. The game goes beyond the sharp textures and high poly models to incorporate reflections, shadows, and intense surreal moments to draw you into the nightmare. What I loved the most is the audio work followed by the pacing, that heightens this short game to a much broader level. Each hour is fantastic, and the build up to the end is superb and not to be missed.

What I loved
- The audio work
- The outstanding pacing, slow at first, heavy on the clues, the fast paced blurs and intesified scares leading to a mind blowing conclusion
- Art design
- Mr. Hat
- They killed Freddy Faz Bear in a van? WTF

What I didnt like
- It's short. Even if three hours is packed to the rim with details and thrills. I want more.
- Needed a little more interactions, I am biased because I wanted more
- There's not a whole of incentive to replay it again, but I am forcing most of my friends and close ones to play it as well >:)

reviewText:
Warning: appearantly there's a time tracking bug. It took me 90 minutes to finish the game, yet my playing time was reset to 0. I had to turn on the game for five minutes to be able to write a review. If you're asking yourself if I did finish it - you get 12 out of 14 achievments when you get the BEE end (you'll see what I mean).

***

Relying heavily on The Secret World lore which I consider to be the most interesting one in world of MMORPGs (just my opinion, no need to prove me wrong), The Park is short and sweet narrative experience. Feeling more like an interactive movie than a game, The Park lets you play a role of young mother searching for her son lost in a local theme park. As the time passes, you'll soon realize something sinister is out there, but the real question is: where's the sinister at - around or inside of you?

Gaming mechanics are pretty simple and the experience is basically a linear ride (no pun intended) reminding me a lot of rail shooter mechanics (although you can walk). That could prove to be a fatal decision in other games, but The Park tends to let you soak up the gloomy atmosphere and enjoy the little horror details. A wonderful and traumatic story is being told not only through words, but also through colors and sounds.

If you're too old to be trick or treating (is that even possible?) or you're simply sick of annual Halloween marathons, do yourself a favor - get The Park, turn off the lights, put on your headphones and turn it up.

Ride of (for) your life!

***
If you like this review, feel free to join me for some more recommendations at http://steamcommunity.com/groups/libereviews

CONS

reviewText:
The Park is an excellent horror descent into madness. Even though it only took under two hours to finish, for $10 I enjoyed it more than most horror films I pay about the same to see in a theater.

For the first 20 minutes I found it mediocre. Some things didn't make much sense, required some suspension of disbelief, and at a few points I was at a loss as to where to go. It soon picked up, throwing in a few jump sacres (some cliche, some really well done) and a constantly increasing tension and creepiness. By the end I was on the edge of my seat, engulfed in the story.

The soundtrack and effects did a great job of making the key points of the game really stand out. The visuals were decent, though clearly limited by art budget in places. (C'mon, guys! The haunted house is filled with stationary cardboard cut-outs instead of at least mannequins?)

And as a technical note, I had to put my graphics settings on Low to make the game playable. I'm not sure why, as I haven't had that issue with any other modern games.

But by the end, the attention to detail and the clever storytelling overcame the game's flaws. If you like horror, this one is worth the $10.

reviewText:
A nice short little scary walking simulator experience, not saying that's bad, just that there is no gameplay to it.

You play a mother who lost her son in an amusement park, and you must go through the park and brave the scares that await you, to find your missing son.

You can complete the game in about an hour playthrough. I'm not sure there is any replay value, unless you missed some of the notes that are around that explain the story.

*SPOILERS!*SPOILERS!*SPOILERS!*

The story is a very good one, in my honest opinion, telling us how this mother, with her issues after her husband's death, attempts to raise her son, but finds it's not all fun and games, oh no, quite the opposite. There may be some truth to how she feels amoungst all mothers, but I cannot say one way or another as I am not a parent nor am I a woman.

I overall recommend the game, maybe a little much for the $13 asking price, but then again, movies cost more than that and are just as long, and in games you can immerse yourself more, so that might be a fair asking price.

reviewText:
Warning: appearantly there's a time tracking bug. It took me 90 minutes to finish the game, yet my playing time was reset to 0. I had to turn on the game for five minutes to be able to write a review. If you're asking yourself if I did finish it - you get 12 out of 14 achievments when you get the BEE end (you'll see what I mean).

***

Relying heavily on The Secret World lore which I consider to be the most interesting one in world of MMORPGs (just my opinion, no need to prove me wrong), The Park is short and sweet narrative experience. Feeling more like an interactive movie than a game, The Park lets you play a role of young mother searching for her son lost in a local theme park. As the time passes, you'll soon realize something sinister is out there, but the real question is: where's the sinister at - around or inside of you?

Gaming mechanics are pretty simple and the experience is basically a linear ride (no pun intended) reminding me a lot of rail shooter mechanics (although you can walk). That could prove to be a fatal decision in other games, but The Park tends to let you soak up the gloomy atmosphere and enjoy the little horror details. A wonderful and traumatic story is being told not only through words, but also through colors and sounds.

If you're too old to be trick or treating (is that even possible?) or you're simply sick of annual Halloween marathons, do yourself a favor - get The Park, turn off the lights, put on your headphones and turn it up.

Ride of (for) your life!

***

reviewText:
IntroductionThe Parkâ€¦ an interesting, although generic, title. One that you might not necessarily link to an amusement park (unless you already took a look at the screenshots). What we all want to know, however, is this: is it a walk in the park or is there more than meets the eye here?

GameplayWhen I say â€˜walk in the parkâ€™ I mean that quite literally actually. Itâ€™s a semi-interactive game but all you do is basically walk. Itâ€™s what people call a â€˜walking simulatorâ€™ these days, and for good reason. Thereâ€™s usually not much to do in games like this and theyâ€™re dependent on the story being told. Anyway, you walk along a set path (you can branch off into a different direction, but thatâ€™s it) while the story is being told by monologues and objects found in the game world and, of course, scripted events. These objects are usually found in the form of documents and books and can sometimes be interacted with, but itâ€™s all very limited. Players of Gone Home will know what to expect. Usually the written material lies hidden in plain sight and sometimes it requires a tiny bit of exploring, but even without exploring you should understand the story without too many problems. Besides reading you will also be able to get on the rides. In fact, the rides are the biggest part of the story.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=543079035
Since the game is quite short (one to two hours) I canâ€™t really go into the story as much as I would like. In fact, I canâ€™t go anything it all without spoiling something. Just saying something short could spoil (a part of) the experience and it wouldnâ€™t be fun for (potential) players, as well as the developer who put (a lot of) time, money and effort into it. If you eventually decide to play this game and you finished and enjoyed it within two hours of playtime then do yourself a favor and donâ€™t try to request a refund. It would be quite insulting to the developer and good art should be appreciated.

The atmosphere is grim and tense and overall the look of the game is dark and moody. It fits the story very well. There are some good scares, but thankfully itâ€™s kept to a minimum to maximize the effect. If that makes any sense at all.

Performance is all over the place and there are some visual glitches. While fine tuning the graphics (i.e. setting everything to Ultra) my entire screen became very blurry. The only way to fix it was to set the graphics settings to Auto. But then the framerate kept going up and down. Unfortunately, it was the only way to get decent visuals so I eventually decided to just play it that way. For game a short as this one I expected solid performance so itâ€™s quite disappointing to see that it hasnâ€™t been optimized properly.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=543079094
Audio & VisualsThe audio design is magnificent: the ambient music is good and the voice acting is nothing short of amazing. The sound effects, while reasonably limited, are solid and help immerse you into the story. One of the best parts of the game.

As you may have seen already the visuals are also quite pretty. All of the models have good detail and okay-ish/decent textures, but since the atmosphere is already quite dark most people wonâ€™t notice or simply wonâ€™t care. In the end itâ€™s nothing groundbreaking and thatâ€™s why itâ€™s such a shame that the game canâ€™t manage to keep a steady 60FPS.

Length/Replay ValueThe Park is a short one to two hour experience. Itâ€™s linear, but thereâ€™s a lot of information (written and spoken) implemented and therefore you might want to play it a second time. I doubt youâ€™ll come to back it after that, though. Thereâ€™s really not much else to do.

ConclusionWhile The Park might not be the best walking simulator out there it does a good job at trying to tell an emotional and thrilling, at times even intense, story. It succeeds mostly, but still has some flaws.
It might not be everyoneâ€™s cup of tea due to the lack of interactivity but if you can look past that (and the horrible performance) then thereâ€™s a good game to be found here, with some great storytelling.

reviewText:
What a brilliant little horror gem.  It starts with what some may consider a slow burn as it builds up the story, but the horror atmosphere just continued to increase until it was nearly unplayable for me (a great thing in a horror game).  There are a number of jump scares once you get at least half way through, most of them exceedingly well done.  What this does is put you constantly on edge, wondering what are they going to do to me next?

The story is quite interesting and takes a dark turn pretty quickly.  It's told to you by the narrator (the playable character) and also by notices and notes that you find.  If you are paying attention, it builds a good sense of mystery which also keeps you on your toes.  The game ends with what seems a P.T. inspired segment that had me in a near panic.

The only negative thing I would say about this game is that the letters were hard to read on my laptop.  Other than that, it was one of the best horror experiences I have had on PC.  If you don't mind the short playing time (1.3 hours for me) and love horror like I do, I definitely recommend getting this.

reviewText:
Be a mom. Chase after your kid into a park of your inner nightmares.  Watch as your nightmares surround you and form the fabric of your own personal hell.

You also may develop a fear of chipmunks.

This game has quite a bit of atmosphere to match its story.  It starts off simple enough, but soon starts down a dark path.  While I didn't find it particularly scary, <goosebumps level?> it still has its interesting moments fear wise.  To get the full effect you need to read everything, as the scattered notes are elements to the story to let you know whats going on.

The voice acting also adds a lot, you can hear the fear in Lorraine's voice build as you progress.

Its a pretty good psychological horror for those into it, as you are never really in any kind of actual danger.  It runs sort of like an interactive movie, while you are free to roam wherever you want, there is more reading and 'rail riding' in following the story.  So if you are into being spooked a little without having to shoot everything in sight, this fits nicely.

reviewText:
watch my video review at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FRqo2Kg6EyU

story

The park takes place in the same universe as Funcoms MMORPG the secret world. In this reality all of Earths myths and legends turn out to be true the boogeman is real and his precense is felt in atlantic ilsand ammusement park.
You play as  Loraine a single mother who is leaving the park for the day with Her son Callum who realises he lost his teddy bear Mr. Bear. Loraine tells Callum to stay in the car while she checks with the information booth to see if anyone found the bear, Because Loraine does not use child locks on her car Callum runs off into the now deserted amusement park she chases after the little brat and you must explore the now seemingly deserted grounds uncovering its dark history while riding the rides and reading letters lying around.
you learn fun facts such as There is a history of children vanishing after dark and grown ups being unable to remember they ever existed. The Park being closed due to a number of unexplainable accidents killing patrons one of whom just so happens to be Callums father. If that was not bad enough their was also that one time the parks mascot Chad the chipmunk gouged out a childs eye with an icepick.

presentation

Visually the park is hit or miss the scenery of the park itself is very well done the rides look great the atmosphere is unerving and the transition from day to night reminds me of entering otherworld in silent hill. However the character design leaves something to be desired. Loraine looks like a robot and when you enter the haunted house she looks like a robot zombie I have never seen a robot zombie before, but that is what Loraine looks like.
The sound is spot on the developers recomend playing with a headset for good reason everything from the rattle of the rollercoaster to docks of the story time boat ride sound steller. The sound team deserves to be applauded.
The voicework is also on point the game uses a mechanic where you call out to Callum and he calls back leading you on your journey. I was able to feel Loraine grow more desperate as the night went on. this was a great touch and for a staff of only five voice actors they all gave a great effort.
I played the game using a wireless xbox one controller, but it also supports mouse and keyboard. The controls are tight, but limited you move slowly and even when Loraine runs it is as if she is out of breth. you may also interact with objects mainly letters that help to progress the story I should mention some of the letters gave me trouble seing them as the font seemed blurred and as stated earlier you may call for calum.
before moving on to the next section it is important that I mention at beginning of the game their is a strange bug that had me restart the game three times before I figured out a fix If you interact with one specific plaque you lose the ability to move This was extra frustrating because it is likely the first item you will interact with and the game tells you to. the fix is to hit escape on the keyboard.  This was the only bug I found on two complete playthroughs but it was annoying.

Dificulty

The park would best be described as an interactive movie it is not like a traditional survival horror game Loraine is not able to die and there are not really any puzzles to solve outside of slowing rides down so you can get onto them. The hardest part of the game might be finding all of the hidden notes, but due to the parks design being linear it is hard to get lost. When you ride the rides it is just that you are riding a ride you may look around and some creepy things might happen, but it is a passive viewing mode. This does not mean the game is not fun as the story is engaging and the atmosphere is top notch, but the game is about as difficult as drawing a circle as that is the path you take.

ending

thorughout the game you will see Chad the the killer chipmunk stalking Loraine as well as glimpses of a shadowy figure that is revealed to be the boogeyman. The player learns that Loraine has been on medication and seems to really hate children. In the haunted house she finds Callum on an alter  and with the guidance of the boogeyman kills Callum with an icepick. Earning her the mother of the year award
the screen fades into Loraine talking with a an investigator who just so happens to be the park attendent she spoke with at the beginning of the game.  she repeats her opening monologue as if she is reliving the horrible memories in her shattered mind. The moral of the story is if your mother tells you to stay in the car you better listen or she will hunt you down kill you with an ice pick.

bonus content

The park has a few unlockables. First there are 14 achievments that you may earn while playing. Most are unlocked just by simply riding the rides and exploring the park. Unfortiatly you will not get anything extra for earning all achievments there are also 6 steam trading cards based on the parks rides you can only get 3 for playing the game forcing you to trade with others to complete the set.
The final peice of bonus content I could not take advantage of because it requires that you have a seceret worlds account. If  you do  have an account  it unlocks a Chad the chipmunk costume as well as receiveing 3 legendary talismans 1 for healer, tank, . This is a neat nod to the players of the secret world, but since I do not play that game I have no idea if they are any good.
I do wish there was something extra to unlock for completing the game maybe the option to dress up loraine as Chad the chipmunk on your next playthrough as it stands outside of maybe earning a missed achievement there is very little reason to replay the game.

final verdict

The park is very short it took me under two hours to beat.The game is linear with little room for exploration best described as an interactive movie. The tension slowly ramps and the last thirty minutes is almost worth the price of admission alone the game has dropped from $20 dollars to $12.99 on steam if you own the secret world this game will unlock some extra perks so if you enjoy creepy games and don't mind jump scares I would say it is worth a play

reviewText:
This game is more or less an expansion upon The Secret World, the Funcom horror MMO in which a player takes up the role of a magic-powered vigilante protecting the universe from that which goes bump in the night.  But this isn't The Secret World.  You don't get any guns, knives, or books to protect you.  And what lies in the dark will look into you.

Lorraine and her son Callum live in the in no way sleepy town of Kingsmouth, New England.  No matter how much they try to leave, they just can't bring themselves to part from The Park, where Lorraine met Donald, the father of Callum.  Unfortuately misfortune struck, and it's left Lorraine and Callum in dire straits.  As a nice afternoon of forgetfulness they go to The Park.  But Callum lost his toy, and so she decides to go inquire.  Unfortunately, Callum's rambunctiousness causes him to escape the car and enter into The Park as the sun sets.  Given permission by the park entrance staff, Lorraine enters The Park to look for her son, and this is where you begin your walk through the park.

I found the game to be very moody, very creepy, and quite intriguing.  The game does build on to the lore of The Secret World, but this game is definitely put together a lot better than the Secret World version of the park, and the park is pretty darn big.  The game is short, but if you're a fan of The Secret World then this is definite a must have.  And it comes with four bonus items for in-game in The Secret World.

reviewText:
First things first, I love horror games...however I get scared pretty easily, so this game did freak me out a little. The atmosphere was on point, some jumpscares did get me (I admit a few times I had to pause the game to recover), whereas there were a few towards the end of the game that felt slightly cliched, no spoilers though.
Although this is essentially a walking simulator, I felt immersed and loved some of the horror mechanics introduced that weren't just trying to say boo!  Little touches which add to the suspense, things moving very slowly, noticing something out the corner of your eye.  Its small things like this which make the game much more interesting.
I was drawn in by the story, which is quite controversial, but I'll say no more.
One small issue I had was the drop in frame rate at the beginning of the game, which took away from the immersion.  Had to drop down to high settings which seemed to fix the issue, but felt that it shouldn't have had a problem running on ultra.
One thing which I think is important in horror games is the audio, again adding to the atmosphere, the devs got this right.  All the little sounds you hear, the whispering, the protagonists desperation in her voice to find her son, and her reminiscing, all added to the immersion.  Best played with headphones so you can hear everything going on around you.
Overall, I would recommend this game when on sale.  I completed the game in 80 minutes.  While it's all about quality and not quantity, some may be disappointed with the content for the price, but if you are after something that's got scares, and an explorative experience, this is great.

reviewText:
Gory thrillseekers, jumpscare lunatics and those looking for mile a minute onslaughts of ghots and zombies probably won't get much out of The Park.  Much in the vein of Sylvio, The Park offers a bleak, desperate slow burn where you slowly explore your surroundings and deal with the mysteries at hand.  There's even less combat than Sylvio and despite The Park's slant towards a nail-gnawing walking simulator the game's formula works and have a way of digging its way under your skin thanks to some frightening flashback sequences, the main character's emotional breakdown and the fact that the deeper you go into the game the more helpless you feel.

The premise is simple.  Mother Lorraine and her son Callum are about to head for home after a long day at the park but Callum left his teddy bear inside.  Despite Lorraine's rocky emotional past with her son she agrees to be the hero and find the boy's missing bear.  Within instants of being let back in the park to begin your search, it's obvious that evil forces trap you inside and soon Lorraine is on a journey filled with taunting phantoms, malfunctional amusement park rides, narrow escapes, suspenseful chases and all sorts of danger.  The game plays out like a point n' click adventure with the player tasked with tracking down the son by exploring all of the park's lucid areas, reading notes that reveal the park's history as well as the darkness in Lorraine's past.  Though you can't die and none of the puzzles are extremely difficult, you'll find the grim atmosphere begins suffocating the senses like a blanket of despair.  The establishment's supernatural denizens will play constant tricks on you, proving that your presence is unwanted.

This game's got great atmosphere with rich graphics creating breathtaking environments, rich backgrounds, lush use of light and shadow and a design aesthetic that gives even The Park's rickety, rustic rides each a personality of their own.  Not only do the graphics create a noticeable feel of decay and isolation but the sound delivers as well with haunting drones, the sudden rumble of ressurected machinery, appropriately evil dialogue from the demons and Lorraine's mental/verbal battle with herself where she reveals some particularly disturbing revelations about motherhood.  This is the purest definition of a psychological horror game as it borrows influences from film including the works of David Lynch, Jacob's Ladder, The Machinist, Session 9, Tourist Trap, Funhouse and perhaps John Carpenter.  The experience really comes together in the dark on a good set of headphones.

As for gameplay, things aren't too deep and there's not alot of actions to perform but they all make sense in the context of this cinematic gaming experience.  You can run, walk, collect/read documents, pick up an item or two, use a flashlight, ride the park's rides and interact with switches/levers and do whatever it takes to progress.  Sometimes time will violently warp between past, present and sheer madness, maintaining an aura of a creeping unknown dogging you until the game's very end.  The story held me in for the long haul and a late game sequence inside of a funhouse gets increasingly hopeless as it progresses.

Though Steam can certainly cough up a few titles disguised as horror that end up being nothing more than incomplete garbage, The Park managed to captivate my attention from the beginning until the very end.  It took me roughly 4 hours to beat the game with all achievements and searching high and low for every single note to read and piece of the story.  Depending on how thorough you are it could take as little as 2 hrs to finish the game in a single sitting.  If anything, the game could have been longer because it really does grab you once you get into it but I got it on discount and was very pleased with my purchase.

Pros:

-Entrancing story well told through notes, collectibles, flashbacks and character monologue/dialogue.
-Excellent setting makes for intense feelings of isolation.
-Well-designed areas and nicely detailed graphics.
-Hair-rising sound design.
-Unfolds like an interactive movie with cool ride sequences.
-Some truly spooky sequences and set pieces.
-Fairly open set-up letting you progress somewhat how you want.

Cons:

-Pretty short even if you're an achievement hunter.
-Not alot of challenge.
-Minimal puzzle solving.
-Really only incentives to play through once (unless you really liked the story, which I did

Overall:  8/10

Despite the short length and some of The Park's flaws, the story was engrossing and the game was hard to put down once I got started.  It's not a typical horror game and wants to deliver a few righteous blows to the player's psyche before all I said and done.  This probably isn't an adventure for everybody but those that enjoy a twisty plot, pitch black atmosphere and a sense of mystery with their adventuring should really enjoy Funcom's admirable efforts!

Overall, this is not an awful game. The story, while somewhat predictable, is decent and the dialogue well-written. Unfortunately, numerous setbacks keep The Park from being something I'd recommend. If you're looking for a horror-type experience, I think you'll find Outlast or even Slender: The Arrival to be better.

My initial experience with the game was less than positive. It took numerous crashes and several Ctrl+Alt+Dels before I managed to get past the main menu and start the game. As far as the game itself goes, there was definitely some things to like. I thought the right-click to shout for your son was a nice feature. The atmosphere is overall well done, but unfortunately short-lived. The game is easily less than two hours long. If you examine everything you might be able to stretch it out to just over two hours.

reviewText:
The Park is like one of those movies that you pay to see once, enjoy it slightly, but never feel that desire to see it again.

After completing this game, I can say I enjoyed the experience. I really liked the atmosphere, and the story, for the most part, was top-notch. The environments were good, if not empty. If you want a spooky walking simulator you could do worse. (but also way better for the money.)

The biggest failure of this game, unfortunately, is that its not much of a stand-alone game. From what I've read is that a huge amount of content reguarding this games story is in FunCom's MMORPG The Secret World If you haven't played it apparently you miss out on a good chunk of content. This includes the ending of the game where players of the MMORPG are given a definitive answer than those of us who have not. This is a big failure in game design. This could however EASILY be remedied by adding more discoverable content in the game, which I hope will be in a future update.

While there are some parts that you can easily omit, for the majority of the game is linear. You will constantly go from one place to another and not find anything, especially towards the middle part of the game. The hope of giving us a typical amusement park with an open world would have been charming, but this game fails to do so. Unfortunately that unlike adding more discoverable content, cannot be added in a later update.

If Funcom revamps the notes/items to discover in the game in order to give us non-The-Secret-World players more closure, I may change my mind. But as it sits and empty abandoned theme park feels like a playable demo ment to advertise the companies MMORPG or give its fans content more suited for DLC.

reviewText: Short and tempting but fails to deliver and barely creepy, yet alone scary.  The setting is great and the overall atmosphere is terrific but, as a game with a goal and challenges for the character to face, this fails.  It barely registers as an interactive movie, at best, with controls thrown in to call it a game.  You, as the player have no choices, except which of the non-story pieces you care to interact with (all optional and do nothing), so whatever tension you may feel in the first few introductory scenes quickly abates to questioning why they would intentionally choose to make every possible movement in the game ridiculuously slow.  The overall experience I believe took about an hour to consume and I was being generous with my attentions, excluding the finale, I'm pretty sure, if you discount time for forced cutscenes and mandatory walking, you've got about 20 minutes of actual player-movement based gameplay, which was disappointing.  Also, the finale is so abrupt, without any chance to interact, even if a lie, a button-time event that at least feigned player control of the scene would have made it that much more involved.  As it were, I felt completely disembodied from the character, the scene and generally just watched as the game ended so, so soon after I just started playing.  The game has all the properties to be great but falls short on so many levels and while I believe it was worked on by a team, it feels like a hobbyist project that was rushed to completion.  I did attempt a replay and managed to confirm all my original disappointments while trying to find anything I might have missed, but the stay on the narrow" path design ensured I didn't miss anything on the first pass
date: so the second was attrociously boring."

reviewText:
Non-violent adventures with little interactivity, the so called â€œwalking simulatorsâ€, are used more and more by the developers who want to make an interactive story. After Dear Esther, this subgenre gained a lot of popularity, but also a lot of criticism that â€œitâ€™s not a real gameâ€ because thereâ€™s usually no real danger for the main character or no way to get stuck. Beside the story, another major attribute of this approach is the atmosphere, and itâ€™s exactly what the Funcom studio made the most of with The Park.

Like a large number of horror movies, this adventure starts in a seemingly cheerful manner â€“ playing as Loraine, you took your son Calum to the amusement park. Colorful, cheerful place where you can have a great time? Oh no, no way, because as soon as you step through the park gates, the true menacing face of this place is revealed, wrapped up in darkness and shadows within which nightmares lurk.

The Park is a game that only had enough â€˜strengthâ€™ for one run. Not only because of the awkwardly written scenario or the lack of mystery and suspense throughout the run, but also because youâ€™ll get to see everything there is to the game during its short duration. This is another adventure where the player is mostly a passive observer, with not enough interesting ideas that made me want to explore the universe itâ€™s set in.

Full review here: http://play-zine.com/2015/11/the-park/

reviewText:
Amazing story that captures the feel and atmosphere of The Secret World perfectly, while still maintaining a uniqueness that allows it to stand on it's own. The game is both engagaing and immersive in a way many adventure style games never quite pull off. The sounds of the game are the true gem of the title, with each area of the park pushing ones nervesfurther to the edge with its terrific use of auditory ambience. I often found myself frantically looking around for sources that I never found. It all builds an atmosphere of dread while providing a disturbing kind of soundtrack to the tale unfolding around you. Though short, it's a great game, that remains true to it's source material.

My honest opinion is that it's totally worth 10/10

As a side note for those who have played The Secret World:

The story unfolding in this tale provides depth to one of the most interesting areas on Solomon Island. It will feel familiar and disturbingly alien to those who have ventured into the park before, leaving you with some new questions. The added depth given by the story even provides further insight into discoveries made in the MMO.

reviewText:
Let's get one thing out of the way: I wanted to like this game. I really did. But I can't. I feel so ripped off by this it's unbelievable. I feel like I've been tricked into paying for a demo of a full game where I only get to play the first level. I've played this game for three hours and I've already completed it. The atmosphere is very 2d and at no time did I feel threatened or genuinely scared. Jump scares are predictable and there is really nothing to do in this game. Pages and diaries that you can discover allude to deep secrets, both of the environment and the characters, and leads you to believe that you will eventually uncover those secrets and solve the mystery of the park.

You won't.

You'll stroll through an empty park, ride a swan, ride an octopus, ride a ferris wheel, have a conversation with Jack Skellington, laugh at a handful of jumpscares (two of which you knew were coming), walk through the same room five or six times and finally be utterly disappointed when you realise that the game has ended when you thought it was just beginning.

In the interest of not being entirely negative (honest), I will say that the voice acting and the graphics were both very nice, with the voice acting of the main character being escpecially convincing. This, however, doesn't warrant buying this game.

If this was a full length game with something other than jumpscares, I'd wholeheartedly recommend it, but because of it's boring content and short length, I warn you against buying this game, lest The Park make you it's next victim...

reviewText:
I had a good time for as long as the game lasted - and that is what counts in the end.
The dark atmosphere, creepy setting and visual presentation really work well.

Be warned that the game is short (and there's not much interaction with the world - it's really more of an experience than a game"). Personally that did not bother me (I considered it a plus actually because it allowed me to play through the entire game in one session with my limited time) - I prefer a good (short) experience over something that drags on just for the sake of reaching a certain amount of "game time" while stealing my time.
The Park will last about as long as watching a movie so if you consider that "too short" for the price asked then better wait for a (larger) discount but don't hold it against the game - I certainly don't regret spending 10â‚¬ on the experience.

I wish the story would have cleared up a bit more because it sort of leaves you wondering about what really happened.
It wasn't until I had finished the game that I found out it is somewhat tied in with "The Secret World" which I have never played so I might have missed parts of the story due to that.
Even though it was short it was still dragging in parts a bit (like the swan ride or some of the scattered text messages) but for the most part it was enjoyable and looked/sounded great.

Game performance was alright (i5-3570k @ 4x4ghz
hoursPlayed:
"High" settings with 2x MSAA for the most part but switched to "Ultra" in the House of Horrors because the low res mirror reflections offered at "High" were just not nice to look at.
It might have dropped to ~30 fps at times but for large parts it felt 60/60 or close enough and when it dropped below that it did not harm the experience much.
I noticed no bugs/errors in my playthrough.

If you enjoy games like The Vanishing of Ethan Carter
voteText: Dear Esther or Homesick you will probably like The Park.\nHowever I have to admit that I prefer any of these mentioned games because they all left a more lasting impression on me."

With a story ripped off from Five Nights At Freddy's and annoying pretentious sounding monologues that don't SHUT THE â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ UP! and feel not out of place from a Creative Writing course at a local community college. This is easily one of the worst horror games I've ever played. I wasn't expecting much going into it, but it dissapointed. Throwing every cliche at you that it can.

It was all a dream ending [Check]
Randomly using gore in place of scares [Check]
Blatantly Dangerous Place None of the Main Characters can tell is dangerous [Check]
Big Lipped Alligator Moments Adding Nothing To The Plot [Check]
Random Creepy Messages For The Sake Of Random Creepy Messages [Check]
Villains ripped off from other things [Check] (Specifically Purple Guy from FNAF and The Babadook from Babadook)

reviewText:
A very atmospheric game that ties in neatly with the story of The Secret World. Graphics look nice and the sound design is also good, creating an eerie backdrop on which the game takes place. There a plenty of small and not so small nods to the MMO scattered around the park and finding those (as someone who played the MMO) has been extremely satisfying. However, since Atlantic Island Park and its story are not only rooted in The Secret World universe but instead the location actually exists in the MMO and can be visited and quests can be completed there ... I found myself at somewhat of an advantage when playing The Park: There are definitely story elements in The Park that I immediately knew what they were about because I played The Secret World. This did not take away from the experience because the story of The Park uses these elements more to pepper its own narrative instead of just telling the same story players of the MMO have already heard again. While it was interesting to learn more about the Atlantic Island Park and the sinister things that go on there, I feel that players of The Park that have not played The Secret World will miss out on some of that closure-bringing knowledge (provided only in the MMO) to some of the more obscure notes and references scattered around the park. Apart from this other complaints I have are the somewhat drawn out ending (I don't want to go into spoiler territory here) and the overall shortness (~2 hours) of the game.

All in all I can recommend the game:
You played TSW, liked the story and lore and want to know more about Solomon Island and Atlantic Island Park? -> The Park has you covered.

You didn't play TSW but like atmospheric horror games that focus heavily on narrative (i.e. The Vanishing of Ethan Carter)? The Park has you covered, may leave you wanting for more when the credits roll, though.*


*If it indeed does - there is a free 7 day trial for The Secret World included with The Park so you can explore Solomon Island more.

reviewText:
A fantastic little game.

Yes, it's short - but IMO it's short for a specific reason... it told the story it needed to tell.  No added 'fluff', no additional grindy parts.  In my opinion, it wasn't longer because it didn't *need* to be longer.

No spoilers, but The Park takes us to some very dark corners of the human psyche, insanity, motherhood - all while in a place that is doing... well, precisely what it was intended to do.  Weaving in the story of the Atlantic Island Park's history alongside the story of a mother looking for her son is no mean feat, but I thought Joel Bylos & Company handled it very well.

The Park doesn't throw tons of gore at you and scream BE AFRAID DAMN YOU!  BE AFRAID!!!"  Instead it relies on clues
date: hints and 'lore' to paint a picture of what's going on - and a rather grisly picture indeed
recommended: if you think about it.  There are a few jump-scares
hoursPlayed:
but I thought they were sparsely-used and effective.

And the roller coaster.  Oh.  My.  God.  The roller coaster.

The nods toward TSW were awesome.  'Nuff said.

Some of the notes were a little hard to read - I had to lean forward more than once... but I only consider that a minor quibble.  Subtitles would be nice for Lorraine's voice-overs though.

Do I recommend this game?  Yes.  Even if you haven't played TSW
voteText: The Park is an enjoyable (albeit very dark) romp."

reviewText:
A very atmospheric game that ties in neatly with the story of The Secret World. Graphics look nice and the sound design is also good, creating an eerie backdrop on which the game takes place. There a plenty of small and not so small nods to the MMO scattered around the park and finding those (as someone who played the MMO) has been extremely satisfying. However, since Atlantic Island Park and its story are not only rooted in The Secret World universe but instead the location actually exists in the MMO and can be visited and quests can be completed there ... I found myself at somewhat of an advantage when playing The Park: There are definitely story elements in The Park that I immediately knew what they were about because I played The Secret World. This did not take away from the experience because the story of The Park uses these elements more to pepper its own narrative instead of just telling the same story players of the MMO have already heard again. While it was interesting to learn more about the Atlantic Island Park and the sinister things that go on there, I feel that players of The Park that have not played The Secret World will miss out on some of that closure-bringing knowledge (provided only in the MMO) to some of the more obscure notes and references scattered around the park. Apart from this other complaints I have are the somewhat drawn out ending (I don't want to go into spoiler territory here) and the overall shortness (~2 hours) of the game.

All in all I can recommend the game:
You played TSW, liked the story and lore and want to know more about Solomon Island and Atlantic Island Park? -> The Park has you covered.

You didn't play TSW but like atmospheric horror games that focus heavily on narrative (i.e. The Vanishing of Ethan Carter)? The Park has you covered, may leave you wanting for more when the credits roll, though.*


*If it indeed does - there is a free 7 day trial for The Secret World included with The Park so you can explore Solomon Island more.

reviewText:
A fantastic little game.

Yes, it's short - but IMO it's short for a specific reason... it told the story it needed to tell.  No added 'fluff', no additional grindy parts.  In my opinion, it wasn't longer because it didn't *need* to be longer.

No spoilers, but The Park takes us to some very dark corners of the human psyche, insanity, motherhood - all while in a place that is doing... well, precisely what it was intended to do.  Weaving in the story of the Atlantic Island Park's history alongside the story of a mother looking for her son is no mean feat, but I thought Joel Bylos & Company handled it very well.

The Park doesn't throw tons of gore at you and scream BE AFRAID DAMN YOU!  BE AFRAID!!!"  Instead it relies on clues
date: hints and 'lore' to paint a picture of what's going on - and a rather grisly picture indeed
recommended: if you think about it.  There are a few jump-scares
hoursPlayed:
but I thought they were sparsely-used and effective.

And the roller coaster.  Oh.  My.  God.  The roller coaster.

The nods toward TSW were awesome.  'Nuff said.

Some of the notes were a little hard to read - I had to lean forward more than once... but I only consider that a minor quibble.  Subtitles would be nice for Lorraine's voice-overs though.

Do I recommend this game?  Yes.  Even if you haven't played TSW

reviewText:
First things first, this game is indeed short. It took me about 1 and 1/2 hours to beat the game. Is it worth it? Yes.

I pay more then that to see a movie which is usually the same length or shorter. The Park is a psychological thriller in which you play a troubled mother searching for her lost son inside a creepy amusement park. The game plays like other narrative games, so there is no combat. As you progress throughout the game the narrative unfolds in the form of mostly notes and internal dialogues.

There aren't any puzzles. You can call out in the game for Callum, and that will help you figure out where to go. Your voice does change depending on whats happened and whats currently happening, and I found that really cool. The atmosphere is good, so is the music. Graphics are also good. However, some notes are a bit hard to read.

What is most important to me when I play a game for it's story is that it provokes an immotional response, and The Park does that.

If you enjoyed games like Dear Esther and Gone Home you will enjoy this game. Also, if you're looking for a dark supernatural story driven experience, you will find a pretty good one here.

reviewText:
So, here's the thing. I want to like The Secret World more than I do. I love the writing, I just hate the things I have to do to get to the story.... also the game has so many monsters it's a little immersion breaking.

So, as soon as I got wind that they made a single player horror game set in the same setting? Gave them my money as fast as I could.

The game itself is fine. I liked exploring the park. I liked walking around and reading the clues. It got very intense towards the end. I enjoyed the atmosphere. I found the voice acting to be pretty fantanastic at time and felt imense pity for the mother trying to find her kid. The game gets a lot of things right is what I'm trying to say.

Problem: The payoff is kinda weak.

The game is way too open ended. Normally I could forgive that but.... everything about it is open ended. You can't have a open ended story without some kind of facts or grounding. There are too many explainations for what happened, and the evidence for each possibility is kinda weak. I feel like it's a better story if you don't play The Secret World because it eliminates some of these options.

It feels less like a coherant story, and more like a English major's wet dream.... which considering one line the character drops it kind of is.

reviewText:
Not really a worthwhile game. It starts off and continues at a really slow pace, without any real features that make it all that different from a free horror game (though maybe if you are familiar with The Secret World you would enjoy it more). Jumpscares are the only real source of horror as the story isn't especially original and the outcome is predictable at the first sign of atypical dialouge from the P.C. The option to call out in the game doesn't change to fit the dialouge changes as they get darker and doesn't really serve a purpose anyway as the path you travel through the game is extremely obvious and linear.

Ultra looks good but even with motion blur off there's a weird fuzziness to your vision through the entire game which ruined any glimmer of immersion for me. You get a flashlight in the last ten or so minutes of the game and can't even use it until you get to the Haunted House section  (filled with cut-outs that are copy-pasted and don't fit the theme of the game much) where it is absolutely useless anyways. The very last bit of the game is a repeated path through an area that gradually changes (like in PT) except the changes don't really matter and just running through won't make you miss anything grand. Anytime the P.C. talks you can't run, and anytime the P.C. gets spooked you can't run, even though it seems to happen at random. There are random little cutscenes that also break the immersion and don't really serve greater purpose than to be a jumpscare.

While there didn't seem to be much point to the rides other than to allow the P.C. to narrate their edgy thoughts on how children suck, I did like getting to see glimpses of the monster guy during them. I thought the roller coaster was pretty funny because with the monster guys hand / weird claw finger next to the P.C.'s, it made it seem like she was riding on his lap.

reviewText:
Great little psychological horror game, good story line which pulls you in from the start and keeps you wanting to know what's going to happen next. The story is sweet and tragic all at the same time as you follow a mother's journey to find her lost son.

Top marks, only wish it was a bit longer.

reviewText: A very interesting game that plays with your mind and your sense of reality.  I use the term game" lightly as it is really more of a walking simulator with some clicking.  You play a mother trying to find her son who seems to be lost in an amusment park
date: but it quickly changes in to something much more sinister.  There isn't much to actually do as you play through the game beyond reading notes and hints about what happened in the park.  There are a few jump scare moments
recommended: but what is really scary is the story and what it implies above and beyond the actual "gotcha" moments.\n\nAlthough the game provides a great atmosphere and story if you are looking for more gameplay then I wouldn't recommend The Park.  The whole thing can be finished in about an hour and there really is no reason to play through it again as nothing will be different or change.  I will still recommend it because I overall enjoyed the story and the presentation.  If you are still on the fence about it I would say wait for a Steam sale and then pick it up."

reviewText:
A profoundly surprising and openly ambiguous game that clutches at the darker, more fundamental pillars of our most primal fears.  Humans are never quite so afraid as when an offspring is lost or in peril and The Park is an excellent analysis of the impact that such loss can cause on a psyche.  Set in The Secret World universe, The Park is richly voiced, well-written and possessed of lavish, creepy atmosphere, with truly dreadful imagery that bespeaks of unsettling evil that festers in the darkest corners of both our physical world and darkest recesses of our minds.  The game is absolutely gorgeous and Unreal Engine 4 is used to great effect.

Everything from the hallucinatory episodes, to the imposing power of the ferris wheel, to the strangling darkness of the roller coaster all present a horrible playground of suffering and darker passions.  The game is very short, averaging about 2 hours with careful exploration and, yes, the ending isn't conclusive or definitive.  The game forces you to be mature, adaptable and careful with your analysis of concepts and events.  The story must be carefully pieced together from logs, article clippings and journal snippets that you discover in your examination of the park grounds but thorough players will soon crack the nut of The Park's labyrinthine ending.

The game isn't scary, per se, but it does induce dread and it definitely has occasional jump scares, like those near the Octatron, and in the midway.  What The Park does offer, is a clever, expansive world, more atmosphere than most games  can ever hope to have in campaigns that are ten times as long, and a gorgeous aesthetic that is sure to please discerning gamers.  The Park is an art piece advertising a game with far more inspiration/content but, sadly, far less style.  Pick The Park up on a Steam sale, turn the lights off, dial up the volume and enjoy the experience.

In The Park, the ride may be short but it's certainly bittersweet.

Recommended:

8/10.

reviewText:
It's somewhat difficult to put a thumbs up on this but I guess overall it's positive.
Pro's:
Spooky
Dark
Creepy
Graphically well made and well detailed
No crashes on my rig
The plot and guidance is pretty straight forward (Linear)

Cons:
The notes you pick up that are hand written are almost impossible to read. The rest of the text youhave to read on forms or on books or signs are clear. This means LOTS of the backstory is lost.
I got pretty sick of calling for Callum over and over. If I ever meet someone named Callum I'm going to punch him in the jejunum.
I really hated the main character. She's a horrible person and shouldn't have kids. I wanted the kid to run away and find a new mother.

It's a solid scare but in a game where there's ZERO action, story is key. Much of the story was lost due to hard to read notes.

And it just ends...but doesn't. Like none of it was even real.

reviewText:
The Park is a wonderful little experance for the world of The Secret World. It is set in Atlantic park on Soloman Island.

The game over all was not too scary, it definitly set a nice mood though out it all and I did like a lot of what it was doing over all with the character and how it all tied together. Is the game a masterpeice? No, far from it. But the game does have a nice plot to it with a decent mystery going on for it.

As for the bad parts about it, the game is short. I am not going to lie. It takes two hours or less to finish the game, but the Devs have that mentioned in the main part of the store so it isn't too big of an issue. And secondly, there isn't anything trying to kill you in the game. Nothing can hurt you and as far as I can tell though out the entire thing, nothing can kill you in the game. One other complaint which was mentioned a few times by others, the handwriten notes are too hard to read.


But, as I said, I am recomending it as a nice little continuation of the TSW world as well as the plot though it all and how it is told has been simply wonderful. so in that if I had to rate it, I would say 8/10 over all.

This game takes place in TSW and it really feels like a mission in the game but a lot more on the rails. This is both the game's biggest asset as well as it's major failing. TL;DR
6/10
Pretty decent atmosphere, Very short, jump scares, no replayability.

reviewText: The play time I had on this game was a little under an hour and a half. While overall the game had superb atmosphere, the pacing seemed to be a bit off, and there just wasn't enough story-telling to make it worth the money I spent, even on sale. There were a few jump scares that worked but most of it was cheap and mostly came at the end of the game. The over-saturation of jump scares right at the end took away some of the creepiness. I want to like the game more but it just didn't have the legs to last, the content was overall light and unfortunately didn't allow for much in the way of character development. The only true scary character in the game, which I wanted to learn more about was Chad, and he only makes a few brief appearances. This game had all the right pieces to the puzzle, it was just assembled in a haphazzard way, that didn't really work. Overall I'd give this game a 6 out of 10.

reviewText:
I wasn't... crazy about this game.... atmospherically it was really cool, but the storyline was a big turn-off for me and leaned way too heavily on the 'the protagonist was crazy all along!' sort of tropes that just... felt... weird. I think i missed a couple of the notes, so I might've missed some pieces, but overall it's a very very short game with a kinda boring/cliche/annoying storyline (as someone with a mental illness who is kinda sick of them being used as horror tropes tbh).

That being said, I really enjoyed the first half or so/before the big finale 'witch' trope was introduced. I thought the rides themselves and the clever use of the strange creature on those rides was really spooky and neat, especially with the octoride and the rollercoaster, and I really enjoyed the usage of the mystery aspect and kinda piecing together the story yourself. It's just the story introduced at first was a lot more intriguing than the mother/son story overall, and once it got to the 'big finale' I found myself really not enjoying the game at all.

Overall, not recommended to buy. Might be worth a watch of a let's play.

reviewText:
Well I just finished the game. It took me ~2 hours to do so.

I am really a big fan of adventure games and horror adventure games. This isn't like the others. I mean that it has some good elements but for the price this game isn't worth it.

I will explain what I mean:

1) The get hint" (right click) mechanic is a little off. It's nice idea but it didn't worked out well. You can hear one moment the girl with broken voice and one sec later it's ok if you use it again.

2) The game isn't really scary. It has some 1-2 things in the late game but that's all.

3) The last part of the game is... a little... too much. Yeah it's cool idea to have something that is change over the time but you need something more than that to have the player to keep up with that.

The graphics are really cool but that doesn't make the game better I believe.

It's a 5 out of 10 for me."

reviewText: The Park is pretty much exactly what it explains on the store page; it's a short horror walking game where you explore a closed theme park after dark. Along the way you learn about the park and the main character, who each have pretty interesting stories. Overall the game is pretty well made, but as a standalone game I think it's somewhat hard to justify paying $10 for it. The real interest in the game comes from its relation to the The Secret World MMO from the same developer, which builds more on the lore of the park and its characters. If you're a fan of The Secret World, I think The Park is a pretty good purchase, but if not, you might want to wait for a sale.

reviewText:
The dark atmosphere of the game is great and contains some nice jump scares. The story is nicely build up, but unfortunately didn't grab me like the brilliant one in Gone Home. Don't expect any puzzles on your way, but personally I believe a game like this don't need them. The last section of the game is the better part of The Park, although the ending is a bit of a let down, in my opinion.

The graphics are good. I'm forced to play the game on low detail settings and a 1366x768 resolution on my laptop (with an AMD A10-5750M APU), but it still looks acceptable that way. Only some letters in the game are a bit hard to read. The music and sound effects are nice and really fit the situations you encounter (headphones are highly recommended). I also like the voice acting.

As you may have already read The Park is short. With 1.5 to 2 hours it's actually very short for a game. But it's worth your money if you're a fan of psychological horror games and you enjoy playing interactive exploration simulators like Gone Home.

I used to work for a certain media giant and its theme parks and exploring the abandoned and left to rot secrets there were some of the most thrilling experiences Iâ€™ve had in my life. I have never played or even heard of The Secret World prior to playing this.

The Park creates an awesome atmosphere through great graphics and narrative story telling. The narration is well voice acted and the monologue does well progressing the story. Each ride felt pretty real and I loved that they werenâ€™t cut scenes and that you had full control of the camera on each ride. The climax of the game was super creepy and really tense. The way the notes are scattered and written is great too. If you take the time to read them youâ€™ll have some idea whatâ€™s going on. If you donâ€™t read any of them youâ€™ll have no idea whatâ€™s happening. I like that in this type of game. It provides incentive. At the end of the game I was really enjoying myself. I was creeped out and trying to piece together what exactly was going on. Then, sadly, they completely ruined the atmosphere that they had set up and ended the game with a third person cut scene. They give you full control over your character for the entire game and then take it away from you for the ending. I have no idea why someone thought that was a good idea. Yes the game is short, but it isnâ€™t a full retail priced game and the atmosphere is great. Gamers need to stop being brats and expecting 50 hour games for $10. I was definitely willing to purchase additional content for the game, to get more of a picture of what was going on and I was sort of hoping that there would be additional content to do that, but after the ending Iâ€™m hesitant and kind of turned off to the story. I enjoyed the game, itâ€™s a good buy for $10 especially since I played through most of it on Halloween but the ending leaves a very bad taste in my mouth.

Iâ€™ll probably play through one more time to really soak in the atmosphere and get the achievements that I missed but I probably wonâ€™t touch it again otherwise. Other horror games like this have been known to follow up with free updates with additional content or maybe even a reasonably priced expansion. Those might get me to come back for another couple of hours but otherwise this is a 10ish dollar one time play through experience. Get it for $10 instead of renting an HD horror movie. Sort of recommend.

reviewText:
It's hard to actually pinpoint how I feel about this game. I don't know whether or not to recommend it, or support people to avoid wasting their money. I'm very conflicted here, but based on the experience, I'd have to not recommend it, my pros and cons will speak for themselves.

Pros
-It's nice to see a horror game take place in an amusement park. I honestly can't remember the last time this setting was used in any horror game. A real shame really, considering the amount of scare opportunities a horror park can have.

-The size is astounding. Seriously, the whole game is huge. I mean, it does take place in an amusement park after all.

-It doesn't rely too heavily on jumpscares. While I am aware that jumpscares are a part of horror, it doesn't focus solely on them. Most of the scares require the player to actually notice them. It also focuses a lot on psychological horror rather than just an enemy chasing you or the boogeyman jumping out at you. It genuinely freaked me out with the atmosphere.

-The monsters and scares are creative. The scares can range from a simple man in a chipmunk suit appearing out of nowhere, to the rides actually attacking you. No, I'm not joking.


Cons

-The quality and rendering is awful. Now I'm not sure if it's just my computer itself, but in order to actually play the game without my frame rate and video quality going nuts, I had to lower all my settings. Like, A LOT. Either the default settings are trash, or my computer needs some work (which is unlikely considering the computer I have). The rendering is also atrocious. The game literally renders in grass when it's a foot or so in front of you. The entire ground ahead of you is bare, but around your feet is nothing but grass and rocks. The rendering also affects the structures and makes them look awful from a distance.

-It's short. Seriously, it's really short. I beat the game in an hour or so, and that was with me just messing around and accidentally riding the same ride twice. Not only that, but I even managed to get all the achievements within that hour time span.

-The pricing is a rip off. Thank the lord I managed to get this thing on sale, and even then it was too high priced. Why is an hour long game worth around $14? Seriously? Considering the video quality and how short it is, it shouldn't be worth $14.

-Let's not forget the filler. I'm starting to think this game put in so many dragged out scenes in order for the player to feel like the game was longer and there was actual progress being made. The intro has an escalator transition that probably lasts around a minute, the swan ride in the beginning of the game is probably around ten minutes long, all of the other rides are several minutes long as well with some inner monologue forced in to make it feel like something is happening, when it really isn't. It lacks so much action and builds up tension when nothing really ever happens. It only gets interesting near the end of the game, and even then the setting is the same thing over and over with a few minor changes each time. The worst part is a supposed story" is forced into the game that makes almost no sense in order to make it seem like the game is more interesting than it really is. Shameful really
date: as it barely makes any sense and was probably left vague in order to make it seem like there was a deeper meaning.\n\nIt's really hard to pinpoint how I feel. I think I would have less of a hatred towards this game if it wasn't for the fact that I spent $9 on it. If the price was lower
recommended: then I would probably recommend it. I guess it's up to you as to whether not you'll buy this game. Thanks for reading

reviewText:
The Park is a psychological horror game that is set inside a seemingly abandoned theme park. The game is primarily story based with the player guiding a mother through the park, interacting with the various rides in order to find her son who is lost somewhere within the park.

The game excellently sets it's tone early on in the game and the creepy atmosphere is coupled with the eerie nature of the mother as she narrates her backstory as the game progresses.

Control wise, The Park is very similar to many first person horror games, such as Amnesia, Among the Sleep, etc. Move with the WASD keys, shift to run, left click to interact. There is no map to show you where you are going as the game encourages exploration. To find your way, the player presses the right mouse button to call for your son, in which your son will respond from the direction you are to go. While helping to build the creepy atmosphere, this mechanic can get a little confusing at times as you are not quite certain where the voice is coming from. This can be fixed in the options menu with a setting to provide a directional guideline along with the vocal response.

The Park's stpry is told through a mix of narration and notes hidden around the park. The narration tells the story of the player character, Lorraine, and her son. The notes reveal the dark history behind the Solomon Island Park, both methods offer quite the unnerving experience as the story plays out, building to confrontations with the park owners and the mysterious man in a mascot suit.

While the Park does sell itself very well, the price of $12.99USD is a bit steep as I was able to finish the game in under an hour, I was able to get it during the Halloween sale for cheaper, so I recommend this game, but maybe when the price is dropped.

reviewText:
A generally positive game experience and additionally amusing as a Halloween buy.  I just played the game though at a leisurely pace exploring around as much as I could.  Could certainly be done in less time, but people saying they played through in under an hour are really rushing it and may also bolt steak and double-fist wine.  Chill out a little and it's a nice ride (if you like this kind of game in general)

Technically, I had no issues with the game other than maybe some very minor stutter here and there @1080 which is natural given I built my PC several years ago.  There are better looking modern games but also plenty worse, and it is good looking enough aside from maybe player character reflections that I was always fairly sucked into the game world.  I did get a laugh at her mom jeans though.

Star wise I'd be between a 3 and 4 out of 5, more toward the latter if you play The Secret World since you get the sicko rodent costume.  If it matters I say this from a perspective of a gamer who is very RPG heavy with some FPS, RTS, and sprinkled misc. in the mix.  I have played TSW as well though not much recently.  I've also played a few horror/mystery type games though not in some time.

As far as $ value (not counting in stars because price may adjust) it does have less replay value due to genre (though I am curious to go back to a point or two) but I'm OK with 9.99.  For me it was like a decent long movie, and which puts current price between a rental or a theater cost so reasonable.  I realize there may sometimes be better deals for pure playtime but also think it ridiculous what some people expect for their money (and some games I wish would move along faster...).

At current price:  recommend to anyone not on very tight budget.
Farther into single digit territory:  recommend to anyone.
