reviewText:
The Park is a pyschological horror game set in the same universe as Funcom's MMO The Secret World. As has been well need pointed out - the game is a brief one and not particular on player agency. The tale on Lorraine and her missing son, Callum, is what is front and center here. Thankfully the story, while not immensely surprsing, is very well told. The use of the tale of Hansel and Gretel as a metaphor to the events in the game is a nice touch that is impressively woven into the imagery of the game.

What little interactivty the game offers comes in the form of Lorraine's voice. By right clicking Lorraine calls out to Callum. This call and response mechanic not only reveals objects to be examined and functions as a guide to the next location, but also gives a window into Lorraine's mental state. The voice acting in this game deserves special mention. What is on offer is very well done.

The Park doesn't offer much. The experience can be had in roughly an hour and there isn't much reason to play again other collecting the two missable achievements or a desire to catch any symbolism that may have been missed the first time around. In honesty, there isn't even much to play" in the traditional sense. This is an interactive tale the user moves forward - not much more
recommended: The Park is a worthwhile bit of interactive horror and well worth a spin for players looking for something a bit more experimental.\n\nWith any luck Funcom churns out more game connected to The Secret World

reviewText:
The Park is a psychological horror game that is set inside a seemingly abandoned theme park. The game is primarily story based with the player guiding a mother through the park, interacting with the various rides in order to find her son who is lost somewhere within the park.

The game excellently sets it's tone early on in the game and the creepy atmosphere is coupled with the eerie nature of the mother as she narrates her backstory as the game progresses.

Control wise, The Park is very similar to many first person horror games, such as Amnesia, Among the Sleep, etc. Move with the WASD keys, shift to run, left click to interact. There is no map to show you where you are going as the game encourages exploration. To find your way, the player presses the right mouse button to call for your son, in which your son will respond from the direction you are to go. While helping to build the creepy atmosphere, this mechanic can get a little confusing at times as you are not quite certain where the voice is coming from. This can be fixed in the options menu with a setting to provide a directional guideline along with the vocal response.

The Park's stpry is told through a mix of narration and notes hidden around the park. The narration tells the story of the player character, Lorraine, and her son. The notes reveal the dark history behind the Solomon Island Park, both methods offer quite the unnerving experience as the story plays out, building to confrontations with the park owners and the mysterious man in a mascot suit.

While the Park does sell itself very well, the price of $12.99USD is a bit steep as I was able to finish the game in under an hour, I was able to get it during the Halloween sale for cheaper, so I recommend this game, but maybe when the price is dropped.

I've also played a few horror/mystery type games though not in some time.

As far as $ value (not counting in stars because price may adjust) it does have less replay value due to genre (though I am curious to go back to a point or two) but I'm OK with 9.99. I realize there may sometimes be better deals for pure playtime but also think it ridiculous what some people expect for their money (and some games I wish would move along faster...).

reviewText:
The Park is an interesting game that's very difficult to nail down. I will give it a recommend because I did enjoy my experience with the game but it comes with the caveat that not everyone will enjoy this game. In fact, I would guess most people will not enjoy this game but for those who can appreciate it, it is an interesting dive into the mind of a mother, torn between societal expectations and her own experiences.

The trailers show The Park as being a horror game but in reality, it's closer to a game like Dear Esther or Gone Home than something like The Evil Within or Five Nights at Freddys. This is because, there really isn't any danger in The Park. You cannot die or lose or anything throughout the game. For me, this realization took away most of the tension I was feeling. There are some creepy jump scares, sure, but I was never concerned by what I was seeing as, for most of the game, there was nothing I could do about it anyway.

Because of this, players are more likely to enjoy the story rather than any sense of accomplishment for braving the unknown. The storyline is split between two major mysteries. Not to spoil anything, as you venture throughout the titular park, you learn about the history of the park itself and the history of the player character, a mother chasing after her son throughout his favorite amusement park that clearly has seen better days.

Wandering around, you ride the various rides in the park which set you up in on-rails scenes which result in something creepy happening or more backstory from the mother. This is really where the game falters a bit. You learn very quickly that backstory will come about by walking to the next ride and riding it. It becomes very formulaic so that you can expect when things will happen. As such, the journey to each ride becomes a bit tedious, further eliminating the atmosphere that the game is trying to generate.

This next bit may contain very minor spoilers but really just my reaction to the conclusion without any details. If that's too much spoiler for you, you have been warned:

So players will be playing this for the story but the story itself, is hit or miss. Well, really, hit and miss. The mother's story with her son is interesting and comes to a solid, if not predictable, conclusion. The story of the park itself, though, is much more open-ended and not in a good way. You are given bits and pieces of story about the park throughout the game but it never seems to really go anywhere. At least, I didn't find anything in my playthrough that wrapped it up. I found this rather disappointing.

Ultimately, if you enjoy games like Dear Esther or Gone Home and would like something in that vein with a bit of a horror vibe to it, The Park will do. It may not be the most memorable or revolutionary entry in the burgeoning genre, but it's worth a playthrough. If that doesn't sound interesting or if you're on a budget and want some bang for your buck, The Park isn't the game for you.

My Experience: Before reviewing this game, I completed the game once, missing a couple achievements in the process. I don't plan on going back for them any time soon.

reviewText:
The Park is short, moody, thought provoking and overall atmospheric little game.
Developed by Funcom in couple month as a spin off - tale for their sublime MMO, The Secret World, it mostly does offer a fascinating peek for the players of the multiplayer game, but also serves as intriguing standalone piece for the newcomers.

It's not the most scariest, or most thought provoking game, but with night time, lights off and headphones on, you can get a damn nice trip for few hours into a amusement park that packs a good share of thrills and rides!

Only gripe I really can think of, well, outside of feeling at points a bit rushed (which is understandable considering what pace this was developed), is that while the little lore shoutouts and easter eggs are definetly nice touch for the existing fanbase, some of them can really puzzle out the newcomers and there ain't really much answers unless you're going to take a plunge into their MMO - and in that sense I think this actually works as kinda interesting first taste to get involved with the game!

I like Funcom's new approach and I wouldn't mind seeing more games like these in future. Nice!

Bearing in mind i'm playing on a beast PC that can handle games like Far Cry 4, Grand Theft Auto V, Dying Light, Fallout 4 and Alien: Isolation on ultra high settings, I should've been able to run this game at a stable 60fps the entire time. However, the framerate is very sloppy when I play. It jumps incredibly high to very low. This is unacceptable even for an indie game.

There aren't much scares in this game at all, really. When you visit each ride you expect to something really eerie to happen but nothing does. This game is boring. For half of the game I sat down not even touching the mouse as this woman talks about her past life. Instead of going to look for her child, she decides to scurry around and go on all the rides. Sure, this would be okay if the rides were actually creepy.

The first ride is actually the worst. It's like 15 or 20 minutes of the game and you literally can't do anything but sit in a boat and listen to the entire story of Hansel & Gretel which everyone knows anyway. Too short and too boring.

reviewText:
Meh

Not a good horror game, not a bad horror game. Just not much here at all. The scares don't really start until you've basically left the actual park. The park itself has nearly no scares of any variety. There's maybe 3 or 4 jump scares, some decent psychological scares (but only at the very end when you're not really in the park). It's got a pretty eerie atmosphere though.

Controls are clunky and slow and unintuitive. The shout mechanic is literally just a waypoint marker.

The story is decent given how very short the game is. I care just enough about the mother to want to know what's going to happen and the newspaper clippings really give the park a chilling history. Too bad the park itself doesn't take advantage of ANY of it's back story. Unfortunately the game kinda just... ends. No emotion from the final scene. Length is also a serious problem. Taking my sweet time I managed to beat the game in 1.5 hours. There's nothing to explore and the very short story is severely drawn out by slow movement speed and even slower mandatory rides. There's less substance here than your typical Saw or Paranormal sequel.

Graphics are decent but performance is meh at best. Given the lack of draw distance, high res textures or overly detailed objects I'd expect to be able to max 60 this game at 5760x1080 with my computer (GTX 980Ti, Intel Core i7 4790k) but even with reduced settings could only get about 40-50 frames. Hardly terrible numbers at all. No serious dips and no choppiness. The graphics themselves are very decent. They more than do the job and don't detract from the game. The occasional animations however do detract from the game. They're simply bad but fortunately there aren't many animations at all. Also the triple screen support is quite excellent I'm happy to say. I didn't have to do any tinkering to get it to work and there is nearly zero screen warp on the outer edges.

Overall I cannot recommend this game. Though it's not bad it excels at absolutely nothing including being scary. I won't even say I was disappointed by the game as it has decent moments. Do I regret my 10$ purchase? I don't. But Layers of Fear is a substantially better game in every way for about the same price. Basically this game feels like the lead up to the very first real scare of a full blown horror game.

EDIT: Honestly no idea why people are saying this review isn't helpful. There's a difference between disagreeing with something and thinking it isn't helpful but... I guess this is the internet we're talking about here. Would welcome comments on how to improve the review or why people disagree.

reviewText:
The Park is a narrative horror story that takes place in a creepy amusement park. While many people are complaning about the length of the game I think it has bigger issues that overall made it less than a great experience .

-The Visual Experience did not meet my expectations . I don't judge quality of games by graphics but this game did market itself as amazing visual horror so I have to talk about it .

Video settings are barebones
Extremely Low Texture which I would describe as 2006 standarts . It looks ok during daytime (first 3 minutes) but as soon as it gets dark its simply below average quality.
Very Blurry Light effects . Shadows are often too heavy probably to hide the terrible texture .
I did not have problems running the game but many people reported poor optimization .
Reflections in mirrows are so bad you have to see it yourself because I can't desribe it .

/One thing I know for sure is that this game has no right to brag about how good it looks/

-Aesthetic opportunities were not taken to the fullest .

Horror House was designed very poorly. Like cardboard pictures really ? They even use same pictures more than once . I have seen better in real life and they couden't take some liberties with a video game ?

Ferris Wheel - you are locked in a camera where you can only see the forest . I was hoping to at least see the entire park but this hole ride is just there to progress the narrative .


-Many jump scares were unnecessary .

For example when they try to scare you with a heavy object coming toward but you can't die in this narrative genre it feels like a failed attempt at jumpscare. They use this more than once and it gets olds fast .

Playing game for the first time I was able to anticipate exactly when jump scares would come . Some were just not original enough and overall its a failure in terms of setting up something scary .

- The story was too obvious .

You can puzzle in all parts about 20 minutes into the game and the rest 60 minutes you just hearing something you already know . Kind of a big problem for a game like this .

I am not sure if this game worth recommending . For $10 I can't . Not because its short . I only enjoyaed half of the game and the big Visual experience was not that great . I am not refunding this game but I will give it a 6/10 score because it was average game in this genre .

reviewText:
This game has to be one of the biggest let downs for me this year for the indie horror scene. We have all seen our fair shares of terrible indie horror games on Steam but this one was just so promising.

This game is wildly short, in all honestly you can finish it in about 1 hour and still get the full message the game is trying to convey. Don't get me wrong this game has some really awesome parts to it that makes it stand out, such as its creepy setting, art style, and beautiful visual fidelity from the Unreal Engine 4.

I will give it to the art designers, they did a wonderful job but fell really short.

This game puts you in the shoes of a mother who has lost her child in a theme park, you must find him as you physologically unravel the mother's mind. This sounds like a good idea, and honestly delievers in some aspects, but in the strongest points it falls so short that it hurts.

In this game you will experiance four slow moving boring rides, with little to no personality. It is a damn shame since the art team did such a great job at the park's design itself. In a spooky carnival maybe you should of put more creepy physological design into it, and turned the speed up a bit more. Every ride in this game is a choir. Yes, a literal chore.

I found the acting actually quite good for a small indie team, and it delievers great on that part! I loved the mother's role as she gets more and more insane as the game progresses. That being said, she really is the only actor in the entire game, so good job nontheless.

The main villian you meet in this game has a really sweet design too! I love how he looks, just so creepy and well thought out. I very much enjoy this aspect.

Also what about that horror part? Is it spooky? Will it make it hard to sleep after this game?!?!? The short and easy answer is no. I wouldn't even call it a horror game, as it only has about 2 jump scares that even work and nothing phsycologically hit me. Such a sad, and dissapointing aspect.

If this game was longer I believe it could of been passable, but with its boring and lack of personality rides, bland story, and overall lack of creepy design I have to say I don't reccomend it but like what it was trying to be. Maybe if they spent more time on it and tried harder, they would of had a great game and experiance on their hands.

reviewText:
It's pretty clear that The Park was inspired by P.T. in a lot of ways. It's basically an interactive teaser for The Secret World which is a fairly decent MMO from the limited time I've played it. The execution here is just far too sloppy and predictible to come close to what Kojima did with P.T.

Predictible being the key word here. This is a stratighforward, linear walk sim. This hurts for two reasons. One, it takes little to no logic to get you from start to finish. It's not a rails, but it might as well be as you let the game holds your hand until the credits roll.

The second reason the game suffers from it's format, is there is no sense of danger or urgency. Part of what makes the best horror games compelling is the survival aspect. With P.T. you had the ghost Lisa that was quite hostile towards you. In The Park you know that nothing will hurt you. Any of truly dangerously feeling elements are in-game cut scenes and the remaining horror elements are a series of jump scares that were all so predictable, I found myself bracing and calling out each. I won't rob you of any, but you're gonna know when they're coming.

When it comes to price, I try to avoid saying a game is too expensive. If I really love a film, I have no issues dropping $20 for the blu ray. Games are the same. Even if it's only an hour long, an absorbing and fanstatic journey can be worth the price in my opinion.

The Park, however, doesn't come close to meeting those kind of expectations.

reviewText:
It was an interesting experience and story that had a few good scares and an overall decent atmosphere. My biggest complaints, and the reasons I have to give this game a negative recommendation start with the fact that this really isnt a game. It is a visual novel. You can read newspaper clippings and walk around and that is pretty much the limit to what you as the player can do.
Secondly, the length of the game is absolutely abysmal. I got all 14 achievements and read pretty much everything there was to read in 2 hours. That is not even worth close to the asking price for this game. I got it for 50% off and I still feel a little screwed over. And you would think that a game this short would at least have replay value or different choices or something, but alas, it does not.
My last complaint is that you can see where the story is going from about 30 minutes in. It's extremely obvious and not the least bit subtle in it's foreshadowing, which really negatively impacts the story's final scenes.

I wanted to like this game and I wish I could give a good recommendation because the premise is gold. The setup of being stuck in a creepy closed down amusement park is exactly why I gave this game a chance, but it just doesn't deliver. I feel more like I just played a tech demo/visual novel than an actual game and that's the most disapponting aspect of all.

reviewText:
The Park is an interesting horror game. Instead of running from monsters, you hike through a forestry theme park looking for your son. I appreciated that the game didn't have villains fighting you, although you will encounter two ghosts that are haunting you.

The controls are extremely simple to master, left mouse to interact, right mouse to call out to your son. I personally did not like the limited graphic options provided, most of the settings are under a single graphics options (low, medium, high, ultra). You are able to set things like AA and Motion Blur. I also kept having problems where my mouse sensitivity setting was being set extremely low, even after raising it.

The game is very short, but the price (I got it on sale) was mostly fair. I beat the game 100% in 90 minutes. After a single play through, I'm not really interested in returning. I would have enjoyed the game more if there was more content. The game basically is a large horror-walking simulator.

I cannot judge the storyline very much as I do not know anything about the gameâ€™s universe. The Park also includes some items for another game by its creators. The story slowly built up as you wander through the park and look for your missing son.

The game gets the atmosphere almost spot on. While most of the spooks are spread out around the park, each section adds more to the adventure. There are a few rides you are able to interact with, and many (hard to read) notes spread around.

I enjoyed The Park and would recommend it for people who like simple horror games. You probably wonâ€™t find the game very scare, minus the few jump scares.

reviewText:
There comes a time when you play a computer game and you seek a story, Something beyond the basic feed of reality. Something real brought to life with the power of extremely powerful sound ambience and a world of visual choreography.

The Park is that story.

Never have I played a more captivating story in my life. This story kept me hooked till the end. I was litterly nervous for the part of the main character and the setting was so loyal to the orignal area in Secret World, it brought shivers down my spine.

A game where you are living the recollections of memories, thoughts and opinions brewed together in the darkness of your imagination. Sharing feelings of fear, worry and disillusioned pasts twirled together in a future concept of mental instability.

I am not one to write reviews of games, to be honost I am the most sinicle player anyone would meet, but to litterly take me down a path in a world so demended and distorted from reality - Where everything has a sound, everything has a meaning and everything has a purpose... I can only say I am left speechless.

This game might not be for anyone, but in all my years gaming, I confess, this is the best money I have spent and would do it again. This story is unique, compelling and holds you on the edge every step of the way.

I appluad everyone who took part in its creation. Your setting was perfect, your audio - out of this world and the story... my god, the story is captivating.

10/10

PS : I am going to play this on the Oculus Rift and relive the story again. I will send the psychiatric bill once I am done because this experience was one I have not experienced in all my life.

reviewText:
It's a great treat for The Secret World players, but probably not from the perspective of somebody that knows nothing about the park and the story behind it from the game.

-The rest of this is probably full of indirect spoilers. You were warned!

First of all, I've heard complains about how the game is just cheap jumpscares, but that is not true at all. The game provides a proper psychological-horror experience if you play by its rules and follow the instructions it provides instantly and linear path it clearly puts you into. I was wondering what's really going on during my trip in the park and why I am seeing what I see. It's mostly an interactive story, a walking simulator, but it's a well delivered story.

The problem with the story though is that even during the events and the rides, you get very little background as to what is really going on, mostly in the form of boring newspapper and general papper cutouts. That leaves those that know nothing about the park in TSW in the black. There are also monologues by the main character throughout the game that help provide a background, but while it helps understand the main character, it doesn't help understand the world you are in.

Graphically wise, the game looks great. It provides a spooky" atmosphere and combining that with some weird events that happen gives you the feeling that you are not really safe even if you know you are. Funcom has never really failed to deliver on that department

reviewText:
An attempt to do something ambitious with the Secret World engine, ultimately crippled by technical hang-ups and a hum-drum horror experience.

Game has style, but its art and graphics will not woo anyone accustomed to current gen console specs.  Some haunting music will creep in from time to time, but is not memorable.  Expect the occasional orchaestra sting to shake you out of your seat briefly.

The story of the game is simple and quick to grasp, with character dialogue that's well voice acted to build up the tension.  The background of the protagonist is well explored and interesting, although relatively mundane compared to standard Secret World stories.

Game is very much a walking simulator.  No puzzles, simply an invitation to explore and spin random objects around in your hands.  Game never quite makes it to scary" but does dance on the edge of creepy from time to time.  Sadly

reviewText: Been playing games on Steam for a while, but never took the time to write a review. I felt obligated to do this one because this game is a mixed bag for some, but I think it is an engaging interactive story, and thatÂ´s very much what this Â¨gameÂ¨is. A spinoff from the MMO, The Secret World, you enter an amusement park, a setting from the original game to explore the sinister stories and tragedies that still haunt this decrepit theme park. You walk along and follow the rides and the narrative, and try to find and read the scattered letters and notices, and listen to LorraineÂ´s monologues about life. I call this an Ã¯nteractiveÂ¨story because you canÂ´t really lose, and even with my terrible sense of game direction, you canÂ´t really get lost. While this gameÂ´s story was not a thriller, with some awesome twist at the end, I found it to be a tour de force that made me interested in finding where the story was going. The main character was enjoyable as a flawed and very human person, and I feel a lot of attention to detail was paid to making Lorraine seem like a real person with real problems, caught up in unreal circumstances. The ending of the game is a bit of a puzzler, but again, so interesting that I continued trying to research the game after it was finished, and even briefly piqued my interest in checking out The Secret World (but who has time for MMOs with almost 200 games in the library). reviewText:
If you think The Park is a horror survival game like Silent Hill or any type of game in general you are mistaken and you will be disappointed.
The Park is not a game. What you should expect from The Park is a 2 hour experience comparing to a good film.

Although it did start a bit slow and at the beginning there wasn't anything truly horror inducing event.
As i reached the later parts of the game this changed though. My heart begun pounding faster and faster from anxiety and curiosity.
My eyes where wide open and i was almost face in my monitor not to miss any clues in the background.
The ending was bitter sweet leaving plenty of room for interpretations and theories about what was/is going on.

For Secret World fans this game is a must.
For non SW fans i would suggest this game without fearing of missing anything. If you find you like The Park there is more stories like this in the MMO Secret World. Even if you don't like MMOs play it as a single player game for the stories within.

reviewText: I bought this game on sale for $9, but I would pay full price for it.  The game is very well written and although it's not very long, its an intriguing experience.  I don't really like scary games moreso because I'm a wimp than anything but I love abandoned/rundown amusement parks so this game really caught my interest.  I'm not familiar with The Secret World (made by the same developer and supposedly has some ties) but I enjoyed the game nonetheless.  I would consider this game more of an experience than anything, sort of like going to a movie but interactive instead.  Make sure you take the time to explore the environment and read all of the notes/pages/newspapers you can to get the information and know whats going on.  I would probably play through this again, maybe next year around Halloween.

reviewText:
Subtlety tends to be what makes psychological horror interesting in games. This game does not know subtlety.

There's a 'deeper story' hidden in the game. Though playing through it you'll find that either.

A) You don't care.

Or

B) You're smart enough to put two and two together.

Not that the 'deeper' story means anything anyway because it eventually goes from whatever psychological horror it was trying to be and becomes a bad LSD trip with a rainbow chipmunk. If you've seen any B list movie ever you've played this pretentious game.
